dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hold on a big slice of MEMPHIS BLUE SKY. The only soun the out of focus American flag whipped by wind in the distance. Soon after we hear, but don’t see - A car pull up on the gravelled asphalt and - The beeping of the door as it opens. From it spills the r sounding out the ‘90s country hit - ‘Check Yes or No’ by George Strait.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE STRAIT
dialogues.text: I think this is how love goes. Check yes or no. And - a fresh faced young man, 18, stands up filling the frame, looking out into the distance. This is JARED EAMONS. He wears an ultra crisp white shirt buttoned to the neck no tie. He is slim and wears his hair cropped short. The camera moves slightly to take in an out of focus chur cross atop a basic baptist steeple ahead of him. All the while - that distant American flag, flapping in the breez flanks him from behind. A second door opens 0.S., spilling out that music again -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE STRAIT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now we're grown up, and she's my wife. Still like two kids and stars in our eyes. - and now - Jared's mother NANCY steps into frame. She is made up to nines: bottle blonde voluminous hair, hoop earrings and t Mascara. Underneath her heavy make-up we can see concern. She slides on Jackie O sunglasses and looks out toward th steeple as Jared turns toward the flag. They both seem lo Nancy hides her concern behind the shades, tries a bright smile and, out comes her chirpy southern voice -

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Are you ready, honey? Jared looks away for a beat, then turns with a convincing smile and starts walking. They leave frame.  INT. L.I.A. FOYER -— CONTINUOUS L.I.A. is an acronym for ‘Love In Action’ -- But we shoul not know that yet. There is no signage. Grey-blue carpet covers an expansive floor space. Stark w walls with no hangings or decorations. Some empty basic chairs lining one section of wall. Heavy doors lead off t unknown rooms. A potted plant in a corner seems an afterthought. N.B.: For now we should see it as a dry, clinical facilit It should feel like a juvenile detention center of some k -- Through the glass of the aluminum framed doors we see Jared and Nancy approach uncertainly - then enter. Nancy’s ensemble is elegant, if not a little gaudy and mismatched: a Southern Belle dress and a shoulder padded coat. She wears heels and clutches a white bedazzled purs Jared's white shirt is tucked into a pair of brand new kh with no belt. He wears rubber soled black shoes and holds book in a blue plastic shopping bag. They look an odd pair: A tall ‘Tammy Baker’ mother escort her awkward, ultra conservative, son.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE O.S
dialogues.text: I help you? What’s your name? Nancy turns, taking her sunglasses off. AARON (40s) stands inside a reception booth: Stocky, with severe hair-cut, he puts a clipboard on the reception led

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: The kid I mean. Unless you’re the one checking in. Jared and Nancy, side by side at the reception desk, sign clipboard document. Aaron stands erect with his authority inside the booth. He too wears khakis and a white shirt, along with a blue tie and a name badge. He sizes Jared up

dialogues.speaker: AARON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s get you checked in properly Jared. Wanna say your good-byes? He comes out from the door of his reception booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see the place?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Afraid you won't be allowed beyond the reception area Missus Eamons. You can pick him up at five P.M. On Nancy, uncertain --

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: It’s okay mom.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Call me if you need anything. I’1l be at the hotel and on my cell ph--

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: We'll be holding his cell-phone. If there are any emergencies we will contact you. Otherwise, five P.M. Aaron punches a code into the door and the door mechanism releases with a mechanical buzz. Jared and Aaron pass through the secure door to a hallway leaving Nancy waving nervously goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared walks ahead as Aaron follows him. When Jared turns, blank expression on Aaron’s face troubles him a little.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Door on the right. They stop in front of the third door and Aaron knocks. So A tall, skinny blonde man (Michael, 24) answers the door. shark grey, piercing eyes are almost permanently set ina judgmental frown, giving him a mean-streak air.

dialogues.speaker: AARON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Newbie. Eamons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael picks through Jared’s possessions, scrutinizing e thing placed down: coins; cash; gum; a plastic hotel key- card; the bag containing the book, and; his wallet. He starts going through the wallet, while throwing the g the trash. Jared reacts. Jared holds out his cell phone unsure who to give it to. Aaron takes it from Jared and puts it with the pile.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Do you have any numbers or photos we need to be concerned about? On Jared. Thinks. Shakes his head slowly. It reads like h not convinced. Michael’s eyes drill into him.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We will check this daily for any ‘False Imaging’ and call any numbers we want to at random. So best you be straight with all this.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: There is nothing... And yeah, call whatever numbers if you need to. Michael, now back in the wallet, holds up a business card And flips it... a handwritten cell number on the back.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Who will answer if I call this number?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Umm. It is my doctor. (beat) It’s her off hours number. I forgot it was even there.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Anything else? Aaron starts to pat Jared down. He finds something --

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. This. It’s... From his back waistband he pulls a moleskin notebook. Mic takes it and flicks through. It feels like a personal intrusion to Jared, who leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just... I write stories sometimes. I’m at college studying and... I forgot cause it’s --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to start getting a better memory. Trust is one of the key words around here. No journaling. We'll need to read this. Again, for any false imaging. (to Aaron) It’s almost nine. -

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Sure. Will I get this stuff back?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Most things you get back at the end each day.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: That's fine. It’s just stuff I - Aaron starts to usher Jared out.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL O.S
dialogues.text: Forgetting something else? Hold. Jared already feels in trouble. Then Michael takes Jared's L.I.A. handbook from the plastic bag. On it we se logo: an upside down triangle with a red heart in it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You need the handbook at all times. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Thank you. It’s the only warmth Michael has offered thus far. Meager

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT L.I.A. HALLWAYS
dialogues.text: Jared is led by Aaron. As he turns the corner he looks ba and sees another young person being led to the check in a - They walk out a door and under an awning toward a large building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared, wearing a name tag, finds a seat and settles into semi circle of chairs with TEN OTHERS: a half dozen teens young people; a few in their twenties and thirties, and; guy in his forties. Three women. Mostly boys. They all ta out their handbooks. We take in their faces as we hear - - The rules read out, starting with Carl: super conserva (25), likely taking time out his retail managerial positi

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: ‘Sobriety. No smoking. No alcohol, or drugs.’ And the CREDITS will appear over - -- during the rules we will intercut with various histori religious paintings and other images -- The Last Supper by Dagnan-Bouveret, Jesus holds up a wine And now to Sarah... (tomboy-ish teenager - all of 16)

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: ‘Off hours. All clients to remain within the ‘Safe Zone areas as designated.’ Les Romains de la Décadence, Thomas Couture. Credits continue over -- An aerial shot of Memphis. Then shots of basic, boring diners and hotels. Family Portrait by Gillis van Tilborgh. NB: The withering look of the central bored male pilgrim facing the viewer. Now - Cameron. Cropped hair. All of 17, he is a hulking l backer in the making with a baby face. He reads nervously

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: ‘Hygiene. Men to shave facial hair, and women to remove underarm and leg hair daily.’ Toilette der Esther - Théodore Chassériau, depicting an immoral woman with outstretched arms. No hair visible. CREDITS continue as we move to LEE. Lee is the SLIM BOY w peeked at Jared in hall. Well: Lee is actually gender flu Non-Binary. Most people, in fact, would have a hard time being certain of Lee’s gender. Lee’s voice is no guide ei way. It is soft and intelligent.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: ‘Attire. Men to wear long sleeves and pants at all times.’ Portrait of Jesus by Del Parson, where a blonde Jesus has hands outstretched in an almost ‘you dig my robe?’ gestur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘Women’s skirts must extend below the knee and bras are to be worn at all times.’ The Virgin Mary in the Rose Garden - Albert Edelfelt We see a flash of a brassier catalogue: dry but sexual. Now PHILLIP (30s. Balding and short. The guy from the hal when Jared first arrived.)

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: ‘Visitations and phone calls to be pre-approved by L.I.A. staff.’ The Religious imagery continues. Credits too. And over to SIMON (40. I.T. Worker type)

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: ‘Confidentiality. All matters discussed in therapy are to remain private.’ The Last Supper: Leonardo Da Vinci. Close on whisperings. ANDERS, 17, is fidgety and freckled.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERS
dialogues.text: ‘Restrooms. Members must be supervised by staff during rest- room visits.’ GARY (20s). Even under the crisp khaki and white uniform can still tell he is a ‘Goth’: dyed black hair; pale complexion, and; black converse. He is slight of frame, handsome and super smart.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: ‘Sexual misconduct. No viewing of pornographic material.’ His reading carries a thinly veiled cynicism that tells u does NOT believe L.I.A. and does NOT want to be here. Jan Breughel & Marshall Paul Rubens: The Garden of Eden. A flash of male pornography.  GARY (CONT’D) ‘No masturbation. No physical contact with any members or non members at any time apart from the briefest of handshakes.’ The Last Judgement by Michelangelo depicting men kissing Push in. We may keep returning to this image - TINA, 27 - super conservative librarian’s hairstyle. Glas

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: ‘False Imagery. Cell phones will be checked in and out each day. Without exception.’ We see flashes of pornographic images PLUS innocent image men in modern society with their arms around each other. As the credits wind up it is Jared’s turn now.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: “Sinful, salacious and extraneous materials. All reading material, films and television are off limits while inside the program.’ Hold on Jared --

dialogues.speaker: SYKES 0O.S
dialogues.text: Very good. Let’s leave it there. Jared and the rest of the group respond to the voice. Som new has entered. Closer on The Last Judgement - Michelangelo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on the various faces as they listen to --

dialogues.speaker: SYKES 0O.S
dialogues.text: ‘IT am using sexual sin and homosexuality to fill a God shaped void in my life.’

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: (repeating) ‘IT am using sexual sin and homosexuality to fill a God shaped void in my life.’ Jared looks around to see the DOZEN or more people that entered and line the back walls. Various men and women of ages. Mostly young. A similar cross section to the seated group.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES 0O.S
dialogues.text: ‘But... I am not broken and God loves me.’ They repeat. SYKES O.S (CONT’D) Somebody tell me what this is. And finally Sykes steps into frame. A man in his mid-fort Greying cropped hair. Piercing eyes. A blue shirt and bla pleated trousers. The only one deviating from the dress c here. He holds up a dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: A dollar.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES 0O.S
dialogues.text: No matter how much you crumple up a dollar bill, you can never take away its value. Even if you rip it, which would represent our being severed from Christ, you can tape it back together. Jared following the logic, soaking up all wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Jesus puts us back together, and even though there is a scar, our value does not change. Behind Sykes is the only signage: The same ‘heart’ logo f the handbook cover. Jared looks across at the androgynous boy, Lee. Out of everyone Lee seems the most terrified.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are somebody. You are worth something. And that’s a fact. The door opens, interrupting Sykes, and in jogs a young, attractive boy in his late teens. Breathless.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nine-O-five Jon.  10.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Sorry. Had to run here. Apologies. Jon takes a seat. Dressed the same as the rest of the gro his cowboy boots are the only thing that sets him apart. Jared can’t help but steal a look as Jon slouches in his chair. As Sykes continues, Jon hurriedly fixes the last couple of high buttons on his shirt. Sweat has rendered patches of the shirt see-through. Jon catches Jared looki who turns away guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Thank you Jon. (beat) Well, I want to welcome all you brave souls. I know the road here wasn’t easy for many of you, but I promise you a smoother ride now that you are here. Welcome to ‘The Refuge’ program. All of the men and women lining the walls follow Sykes’s in applauding the NEWCOMERS that are Jared's group.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, you guys. Get back to your schedules. And with that, all of the men and women lining the walls start to file out. Jared watches them.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Jared’s group) So we can get down to business. He crumples the dollar bill and throws it to Cameron, who catches it.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t spend it all at once. Jared feels buoyed by Sykes’s rhetoric and light energy i the room.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This may be the toughest but the most rewarding twelve days many of you will ever face. (Jared and four others) We have only one task. Simply to bring ourselves back to God. To invite Him back in. T’understand how he truly meant to create us. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYKES (CONT’D) Before those pieces got torn away. (beat) ‘What sinful things have you done?’ And to ask God's forgiveness. (beat) Discover who made you this way. ‘Who led you into sin?’ (beat) And get you on the right path to a life restored. (beat) I tell you, we are all about to go on a wonderful journey together. Who’s ready? (smiles) That was a question. Everyone either raises their hands, nods, or utters ‘yes.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you are ready, say ‘Amen.’

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE /JARED
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: If you know you’re worth a dollar, say ‘Amen.’ Jared feels suddenly good and swept up in the new atmosph in the room. For the first time we see him smile.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE O.S
dialogues.text: As the title disappears, a more personal silence develops

dialogues.speaker: JARED O.S
dialogues.text: Please Lord, make me pure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s tea break. Jared sips tea as he looks around. - Sykes speaks to a fellow staff member.  12. - Sarah sits alone, eating cut carrots and celery. - Lee sits doing nothing. Totally lost. - Nearby, Jon talks with Carl; the super conservative managerial type. Then Jon salutes him in a casual, milita style. During this Jon and Jared catch eyes. Sykes claps his hands together.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Okay. Bring it in. Jared approaches his chair. Next to him is the VERY large very young, linebacker-type, CAMERON. A gentle giant. The sneakers, the calloused hands, and the crew cut sugge he was probably blocking a touchdown rush last Friday nig to the roar of his high school home crowd. Now, for reaso that he seemed to be puzzling in his head, he had found himself locked in at L.I.A.: The roaring stadium bleacher now replaced by a prison. Jared and Cameron acknowledge each other. He is painfully shy, clutching his L.I.A. handbook, wishing it was just h team’s playbook. Something he fully understood. Jared catches eyes again with Jon, who gives him a mini salute. SYKES O.S. Who can tell us what a Genogram is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the group. Finally, Phillip raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: A Genogram is like a family tree. Only, one that shows patterns of family behavior as well. But, like, an illustrated one.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Someone read the handbook. Thank you, Phillip. Michael moves through the room with big sheets of butcher paper and plastic tubs of colored sharpies for each membe  13. SYKES (CONT’D) A Genogram shows hereditary patterns and behavioral clues in our families. It traces the history behind our sinful behavior. (beat) Be as expressive as you will, but write a list or draw these folk in your family. Anyone of influence to you as you grew up too. Blood or otherwise. First sexual partners even. Teachers. Coaches. Jared looks across at the other members, curious of their various stories and histories. Sykes goes to a board where Michael is furiously writing list of ‘behaviors.’

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then write next to these people, their sins -- All members, old and young, start to sprawl out on the gr like children drawing. Jon and Sarah, already familiar wi the task, are writing out family names and drawing etc...

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Michael -- Michael’s sounds out the codes. MICHAEL O.S. A. Alcoholism. P. Promiscuity. H for homosexuality. D for drugs. A Money sign for Gambling. M for mental illness. Big A little b for abortion. G slash C for gang or crime involvement. Big P little o for pornography. Jared looks to big Cameron as he writes slowly -- M..o..m

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: You're forgetting... oh ‘Dv.’

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. Big D little v for domestic violence. Cameron now adds ‘Dv’ next to his Dad.  14.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Call them out in your Genogram. Because I can guarantee, and you may not even realize it yet but, one or some of these people are to blame for why you are here. Jared looks down at his page. He has listed - Dad, Mom, Grandpa W, Grandma W. Nan. Poppy. Uncle Chris. Aunt Minny Now, his hand wavers over what to mark any of them as. Sykes’s feet step before Jared’s poster. SYKES O.S. Search your mind and you'll find something. Sykes crouches down. Jared, out of fear of coming up blan writes ‘A?’ Next to Uncle Chris.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: You know or you don’t know. ‘Uncle Chris is an alcoholic.’ Jared erases the ‘?’. He looks at Sykes’s feet, thinks, a then writes Chloe... ‘P’ - (promiscuous) PRE-LAP - The roar of a crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed bleachers out of focus. Then in poetic slow motion see a BEAUTIFUL YOUNG CHEERLEADER fly into frame. A sequi red, white and blue uniform with a big ‘M’ on the chest. throws a shape in slow motion, beaming a THOUSAND WATT sm

dialogues.text: Title card : CHLOE Gravity takes her away again, but soon she is back, bendi into an even more brilliant and dynamic shape.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE O.S
dialogues.text: Chloe wants to have sex with you. She lands now,_in real time and the sound returns to norm

dialogues.text: Jared sits on the bench, leaning into his friend Wayne. H didn’t hear. Basketball players press in front of them.  15.

dialogues.text: I said Chloe is down to do it. She's been asking Mindy and Mindy has been positive for obvious reasons. So you can thank me. Before Jared can respond - The buzzer rings sounds and th St. Martin’s Colonels, basketball team are in a GROUP HUG Soon, friends and family members are among them offering congratulations. Jared's parents approach. We recognize Nancy but his dad will now meet: MARSHALL. He limps over in a mismatched bl and pants. A sturdy man in his 50s.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yay!!! You set up so many points. I saw -

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: - Most underrated component of the game, assists. And you scored some too. Congratulations. A handshake turns into a hug. A rare commodity.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's victory sweat.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Eww.

dialogues.text: I only played five minutes. Chloe approaches --

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Yay!! Congratulations!!! Woo-hoo!!! She hugs Jared still holding her pom-poms.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (lights up re: Chloe) And weren’t you something. Another underrated component of the game. Nancy playfully hits her husband.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Moral support. Seriously. How high up were you just now?  16.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We were worried. What if they dropped you? Chloe takes Jared’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You kids going to celebrate? Marshall holds up a Ford key. It’s a big deal, his father giving him the keys to the car.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s yours. (off Jared's surprise) The dealership are putting me ina new Explorer Sport. You deserve it. Have fun. Jared launches in to hug his dad. Chloe joins.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was going to be for your birthday. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Wayne!! He holds up the keys to his teammate and friend, Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: No more people than it has seat belts. INT. JARED’S ‘02 FORD MUSTANG - NIGHT. ARKANSAS. SUMMER. A JAMMED CAR. Just the opposite of what his father ordere Jared and Chloe ride up front. In the back are two couple Wayne and Mindy, along with Lance and Cheryl. As they pass parked cars, and kids walking, we see a LAKE the B.G. KIDS are already stripping down and jumping in. They park and everyone goes to get out. Chloe pulls Jared back for a kiss. After a couple of attempts he pulls away

dialogues.text: Come on.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sprawl of wet, undressing youth all in bathers or underwear. Jared strips down and heads for his teammates who are alr splashing in the water. He passes - A flat-bed truck that is reversed close to the water’s ed A couple of guys are trying to set up speakers. Meanwhile Chloe and the girls undress more carefully, hanging cloth in trees or folding them into neater piles. Then the music BLARES, received with a victorious cry. Br Me to Life - Evanescence. Another cheer rings out simply the choice of song. Through the opening riff - The girls continue to undress while -— In the lake other kids start to ‘air-drum’ to the song. Jared and his mates tune in too, all playing their air guitars. Then, as the song shifts gear, Wayne splashes La and the others and they start to wrestle and play-fight - Jared jumps into the fray, grappling with Wayne, fully committing to the camaraderie. Then - Wayne breaks free.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Holy.... Dude. Check it out. And then Jared turns to see - - what would normally make any teenage boy quiver immediately: Chloe in a white bra and panties, semi see- through when wet. She is full breasted and wading, barely deep, in the water. The boys all stare - at the trio of girls: pure teenage fantasies wading in the lake. Jared t back to the guys.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bro. What’s wrong with you? Go. Go. That’s the trophy. The guys all push Jared toward Chloe. It’s a slow approac

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know white is see through when it’s wet Chloe? A few chuckles from the boys.  18.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I heard that laugh before. I think on a documentary about hyenas... that were retarded. And their retarded friends. Jared laughs like a goof at Chloe’s joke.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You may as well take it off, cause we can pretty much see it all.

dialogues.text: Shall I..? Okay... (she teases) Oh, But I wouldn’t want you guys to pollute the water with all your...

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Say it. You can’t even say it.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Cum. Shock. Off Wayne’s expression she turns to the girls.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See. He just did I bet. You guys actually have hard-ons right now don’t you? Blank expressions. Wayne gives an ‘as if’ response.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Damned if you do. Damned if you don’t. Then - Chloe splashes Jared, breaking the tension and the all start to wrestle, thrashing in the water.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and Wayne by the bonfire. Lance and Nick dress clos by. Wayne offers sage advice on sex -—

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: What’s it like?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: We've done it four times now. Jared nods. His friend is an expert.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s pretty awesome dude. I have to say. I mean, I’m sure it’d be even better just relaxing on a nice bed instead of in the corner of a barn or in some dark closet with an actual real fear of getting caught and shot by Mr. Riggs. But - Even still, it’s a-mazing. (beat) It’s like being in a place you've been told over and over is bad and then you get in there and you are like - ‘how is this bad? I wanna be in here forever.’

dialogues.speaker: LANCE
dialogues.text: Like White Castle.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Like eating a burger??

dialogues.speaker: LANCE NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like shut up. You compared sex with a girl to eating shitty food. Lance punches Nick and Nick returns fire. Soon they are u wrestling each other. Wayne and Jared. LANCE O.S. Get off me, fag. Faggot!!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: It’s warm. And it gives you this amazing great feeling.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I bet yeah (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Plus, man. Listen. This whole no sex before marriage thing... would your dad expect a customer to buy a car without test-driving it? See. You almost have to try it. (good point) You won’t wanna stop dude. Seriously. Try it. You'll see. This lands with Jared. The thought that maybe sex with Ch could make him snap out of his thoughts aimed at men. He looks across at her on opposite side of the fire. She has finished dressing and wears his hoody. INT/EXT JARED'S FORD / CHLOE’S FAMILY HOME - NIGHT Elton John's - “Sad songs said so much" plays as Jared pu up to Chloe’s family home. Their hair is still wet.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Go back behind the tree.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I should get home. I -

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: We are fifteen minutes early. He reverses so a large maple tree blocks the view from th house to the car. She immediately starts to kiss him. Jar engages. Then his eyes open, looking down -- A hand, Chloe’s hand, is on his thigh. He stops her.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? I just wanna touch it. (beat) On the outside. Jared keeps his hand on hers.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If it’s not hard, I can make it hard.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: We should wait for that kind of -  20A.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I’m not asking you to put it inside me, Jared. I just wanna feel it through your jeans (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: . Wayne and Mindy have gone all the way and they didn’t get struck by lightning or put in prison. Cheryl has put at least three in her mouth that I know of.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Cheryl?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I just wanna feel it.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: If we start that, then it’s gonna be hard to stop. I want to but shouldn't we wait until, you know -

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: You asking me to marry you? (beat. Silence) That's what my parents think should happen. To keep us together through college. Jared is at a loss for words. Then Chloe tries one more t He stands his ground. She sits back defeated and opens th door.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is wrong, Jared? Jared is left alone, aware this is an escalating issue. INT. EAMONS FAMILY HOME - JARED’S BEDROOM - DAY Jared, shirtless, staring at a screen. He types something quickly and bites his nails and checks the door. Circa 2004 downloads were not so fast so it starts with t top inch of a man’s face then, five seconds later, the ne and bare shoulders. A slow motion strip tease.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY O.S
dialogues.text: Jared honey? Jared tries to shut the screen but gets the ‘spinning whe The image is stuck halfway. He tries again but the image downloads one bar further. Nancy approaches. Thinking qui he turns the screen to black.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm starting a new painting. Which one do you like best (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She holds up two images (both of the family). He picks on She stays there continuing to look at the photos.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Mom, I’m getting dressed. On her way out.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Make sure you pack for Dallas. I think your father wants to go straight from church tomorrow. Nancy leaves. Did she see or not see the glistening muscu man in the underpants ad? He brings the screen up again. image, no longer enjoyable, is a just source of guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall sits at the breakfast table. Jared shuffles in dressed in a similar shirt. Jared goes to the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: We'll detail that car today.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Dad, seriously, it’s so awesome.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Are you ready? I’1l ride with you --

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Why are we actually going to Dallas?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: The architect has updated the remodelling plans for the ministry and we are taking a tour of two similar churches there.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Do you think I could stay at Chloe’s when you go instead? (Off Marshall’s look) It’s okay. I can stay at Wayne’s or I‘1l just come. I’1l just come.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I’m okay with you staying there, if they are. I think it’s a good idea (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and his father get in Jared's car as Nancy waves to them. She is setting up her easel and paints beside Marshall's other hobby: a restored ‘65 Chevy Pick-Up. MARSHALL O.S. You are both mature kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared's car turns into the Ford dealership. INT. EAMONS’S FORD DEALERSHIP - DAY Jared walks through the dealership following his father. Jared shakes Big Jim’s hand and is greeted by other worke MARSHALL O.S. Who know how to conduct themselves -

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Big Jim. Lead us in prayer today?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Be proud to Captain. Jared. MARSHALL O.S. - and who know by now how the world works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There among the display cars Jared, Jim, AND FOUR OTHER C WORKERS, lock arms in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Dear Heavenly Father. Thank you for this day filled with sunshine --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared devours ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ over lunch --  24. MARSHALL O.S. You gotta learn to take small steps toward manhood, so that you don't have to run, panicking, when it suddenly arrives. Across the table, a voluptuous female employee eats lunch reading a magazine. Jared shares an awkward smile with he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Jared, flanked by Nancy, watches Marshall preach.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Let’s see a show of hands -- Wayne, who sits next to Jared, palms him something. A con He winks. Jared is mortified.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who knows they are imperfect? Everyone’s hands go up. Jared swaps the condom in his han to comply with all the hands firing up in the air.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And those that are? No hands - a polite chuckle from the congregation —

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, that seems like the perfect segue to my introduction. Jesus spoke to me the day I saw this man first speak, and said ‘listen to, and learn from, this man.’ Which I have done every week in this very church. He has helped me immensely and given me the strength to start my own mission at Mountain Home. Jared catches eyes with Chloe -  25.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s about as perfect as any man can get in this world and in his true service to the Lord. My mentor, Pastor Lynn Marks. He passes the mic to the elder Pastor. Marshall then sits front of Jared and turns with a smile and a weird high- five/handshake. Pastor Wilkes climbs the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR
dialogues.text: Everybody stand up. On your feet. And such is Pastor Wilkes’ power: the congregation stand. INT. CHLOE’S FAMILY HOME - NIGHT Jared sits for dinner with Chloe, her parents ERIC and BR and her fifteen-year-old brother CHRISTOPHER. Secretly, C reaches her leg out to touch Jared’s thigh.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: So a semester at Lyon, and then Chloe was saying you hope to bridge over to U.N.C by next year?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. They have a great writing program. Journalism really interests me -

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Well. We'll have to find ways to keep you guys connected. Looks all around. The conversation is loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark. Jared sits up to check on a sleeping Christoph His phone receives a vibrating text -—

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: ‘??? come up’  25A.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: (texting back) ‘okay. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared moves ever so quietly up the stairs. But then - CHRISTOPHER O.S. Where you think you're going? Jared frozen, turns to see Christopher. Sprung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared plays Dynasty Warriors III with Christopher. The mu is synthesized and upbeat. The character, Zhang, looks li an Asian rock prince, clad in purple silks, wearing a sli hair topped by a tiara. He swings a four pronged sword.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: What do you think of him? What’s- his-face, Zhang He, there with his girly crown and pony tail in the purple outfit moving around like a dancer.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s a bit much.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: A bit gay don’t you think? Jared looks at Christopher. CHRISTOPHER (CONT’D) Don’t you think? They stare at each other. Something shared in the look. Dangerous and also tender. There is a wisdom to Christoph for a younger kid. The silence broken only by a text mess CHRISTOPHER (CONT’D) You wanna go and fool around with my sister, I ain’t gonna stop you. Hold.  26A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared stares at the ceiling, then finally turns to fall asleep. He’s given up the attempted mission. cuT TO  27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared stands back from his Genogram and stretches. He mak some notes on his L.I.A. notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared is handed a zip-lock bag containing his possessions Michael. Jared opens his phone, just to check it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Tomorrow at nine. Jared starts to walk toward the exit, as Michael moves ba down the bowels of L.I.A. Jared turns, holding his Molesk

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Um. Hey. You tore out the pages -

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: False Imaging. Jared looks at the book with the pages crudely ripped out

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: They're just... stories.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Sykes will decide that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared comes out quietly fuming, holding his bag of items. is on the steps waiting. Jared sits a little way off.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Whatever they took, you’ll probably get it back. Don’t sweat it. Jared tries to let it go.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Were you in the military? I saw you salute. I thought --

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Oh. That. No. I could do the whole handshake thing. I’m just trying zero contact what-so-ever. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Twenty-three days now. So I - (he salutes) Salute instead (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jared nods awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sure it don’t feel like it right now maybe but you’1ll love it here. You get all sorts but this group seems good.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Have you been here before?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: It’s my second go round in the Refuge Program. I started a couple days late last time and - (beat) I'm actually waiting for a place to open up in one of the houses.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: What houses?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Down the back there, past the fence they got a couple houses for the long-stayers. New Hope house for the men. One for the women too. (points) Those others you saw earlier today, most of them stay there. (beat) Meanwhile, I’m at the Best Western while I wait for my spot. Assuming you're staying at one of the local ‘safe zone’ hotels with a relative too? Jared takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: How long will you stay for?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: That’s not really up to me. Sykes decides - sometimes six months. Or else a year. You eighteen?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Just. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Then you can stay at the houses.  28A. Off Jared’s look -  29.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nobody explained that to you? This is just an assessment program, The Refuge. To see what to do with you next. Just then - the doors open and out walks Sarah flanked by Aaron on one side and an older man, possibly a stepfather the other. Everyone watches as she gets ‘put’ in the car an escorted prisoner. Jon takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Should’a seen her arrive this morning. She’ll be fine. Like I said: ‘all sorts.’ Some are ready for it. Some not. This hangs. Is Jared there by choice or by force? He catc eyes with Gary who leans against the fence.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lean into it man. It’s the only way to do it and win. S’only way it’s possible. Just lean in. (beat) And it is possible. If you’re on your heels you’ll lean too far away and fall backwards into hell again. No point not leaning in when you get given the chance. Jared absorbs Jon's optimism. He already has identified h as someone to look up to.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Yeah. No. I’m excited to be here. Suddenly Nancy pulls up and leans out the window -

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Hey! How was it? Was it fun and interesting? Jared stands up, a little embarrassed. She waves to Jon -

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m the Mom. (no response) I’1l1 turn around. Nancy starts the turn as Jared gets set to leave -  30.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: You need a ride? I think we’re just near the Best Western.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Someone's on their way to grab me. Thanks though. And don’t sweat the things they took. Lean in. Think of the bigger picture. He salutes from his perch and Jared starts off - Jared passes Cameron who gets into his Dad’s suburban S.U At a first glimpse, CAMERON’S DAD, a wealthy man, looks l an ex-football player.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: See ya Cameron. Cameron turns sweetly, flattered to be acknowledged. But father turns sharply to assess Jared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy’s car pulls onto the highway, into the dimming Memp sunlight, toward the glowing row of cheap hotel lights. Jared winds down the window and puts his arm out, dancing the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Please don’t do that. I’ve told you that makes me nervous. What if a truck comes and...

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: That is never going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s happened before. It has. He pulls his arm back in and winds the window up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and his mother eat. She keeps looking at him. Jared puts his fork down decisively as if to say ‘what?’ --

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well? I wanna know about your day (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: We're not meant to talk about it outside of group.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don’t need gossip. You can speak generally.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I’m going to lean into it. And there are some good people, and yeah. I like it. They go back to eating, Nancy relieved. He seems happy. J thinks a beat and finally takes a piece of paper from his pocket and places it beside Nancy’s plate.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do we have people in the family who had issues with any of this stuff. Nancy examines it, getting her reading glasses.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: ‘Pornography?’ The people at the booth behind turn and she lowers her vo

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Drugs.’ ‘Gang affiliations?!’ What is this?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I need to know for homework.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Gang affiliations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and his mother walk the long hall to the room. NANCY O.S. Why does the family matter? Our family is so... normal. As Nancy enters the room, Jared clocks Sarah and her stepfather a little way down the hall  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared puts his schedule on the wall. He takes his L.I.A. handbook and homework and piles them on the nightstand. H weighs his own books he brought for the stay -- now certa ‘off limits.’ About to place them in the trash, he thinks better of it and piles them over on his mother’s nightsta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy enters from the bathroom and places a piece of pape the top of his L.I.A. handbook: Jared’s Genogram homework

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Sleep well. Big day tomorrow. As she walks away, he examines the paper.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was only with the gang for a year or so... Until I went down for drugs, and got sent to prison.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Ha ha. Jared leans over and switches off the lamp. Then after a pause in the near darkness we hear - NANCY O.S. I put your Uncle Victor down there. We never see him. He moved to Louisiana. We always figured he might have been... well, he was very feminine-like you might say. Jared stares at the ceiling, the traces of light outlinin his face. SYKES O.S. What is a real man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON JARED’S GENOGRAM. It now has a handful of ‘A’s a and ‘Dm’ in both grandparents lines. And a new BOLD addition... UNCLE VICTOR -- ‘H.’ (Homosexuality) SYKES O.S. What defines a ‘real’ man? Close on Cameron’s child-like drawing of his dad: Brutish  33. SYKES O.S. (CONT’D) Perhaps being close to the flames of hell and finding your way back forges a great strength -- Jared and the others pin their work to the back wall. Fro his position near the big open door, Jared can see the fe line outside: A big black Chevy pickup parks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the members of the group as they keenly watch th ‘newcomer.’ SYKES O.S. And if so... if this isn’t a real man, I don’t know what is. Sykes is almost too excited to introduce their guest staf member. And we finally see him -

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Meet Brandon Ellis. There is no mistaking, Brandon is a hard man, who’s lived hard life, and walked a hard road. That 1% that makes mos self-proclaimed men feel ‘less than.’

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Over to you Brandon. Sykes tries a tough-guy handshake. It is comfortable on Brandon. Not with Sykes.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: Thanks Sykes. Mighty kind of you and... God bless. (beat) A ‘real man’ to me is a man of God first and foremost. I’m a man of God no doubt. But, I wasn’t once. If I was ever listed on my own son's Genograms - God forbid I was and that he were here - In that comment we see not just Brandon’s thinly veiled disgust for homosexuality  34.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - But if I was: Drugs. Violence. Prison time. Gang crime... I'd have so many letters next to my name, it would look like qualifications from some university. (pause for effect) And I actually believe that to be true. I’m qualified to be here, not Maybe because I have ever had the kinds of thoughts and feelings that y'all are wrestling with. Or that your other guidance counselors have overcome. There is the disgust again. PLUS it dawns on Jared that m of the staff may be ex-gay. He steals a look at Sykes.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I’ve had all sorts of my own trials that took me so far from the Lord, it is a true miracle that I am standing here before you. But I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and the gang all ride the short bus. Brandon and Sy flank the aisles near the front. Aaron drives. We are not sure where they are headed. Jared turns for a moment and looks down the aisle - perhaps to see Jon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole group are in a line. Brandon moves along spread the guys’ stances wider, and correcting posture while Syk and Aaron and the girls sit on the concrete bleaches.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: Standing. Leaning. Sitting. It’s all the same idea. Triangles are the strongest shape. This. (he shows a wide stance) Not this. (a narrow one) Okay, hand or hands on hips. Go. Brandon claps and each boy/man lifts their hands to hips their own manner. It’s a drill they’re being subjected to  35.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to what he sees) Fingers forward not backwards S'just the way it is. Elbows out. Not back. S’just the way it is. Triangles. Triangles. Sykes watches with his hands on his hips. Not exactly the picture of manliness, he adjusts his own elbows out a lit

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think of the shapes you are making and ask yourself... ‘Is this a manly shape I am making?’ Or, ‘is this a girly or a feminine shape?’ On Sarah frowning. She is sitting this one out. But she’l serve another purpose.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sarah? I want you to arrange these guys in a line in terms of masculinity if you will. Least to most. Jared and the others look around, wondering where they mi fall on the line. Sarah tentatively starts in on the task

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Myself, and other alcoholics and addicts put their faith in AA. Get familiar with this phrase - (beat) ‘Fake it until you make it.’ Sarah struggles in deciding who is on what side of the MA evolutionary chain of L.I.A.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Do it Sarah. Don’t think. Just do. Sykes’s authority seems diminished by the mere presence o Brandon, the clear biological ruler here. Jared is moved along by Sarah. He is placed somewhere in middle next to Gary. They share an awkward friendly nod. Sarah has placed Lee at one end and Jon and then Cameron the ‘Most’ end. Cameron gets the crown. Sarah stands back and Brandon steps forward. He walks the line starting with Lee... his face hides nothing in his confused assessment of Lee. As he completes the line -  36.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: Perrrr-etty good. Brandon moves to face Cameron, who stands at least five inches taller than him. He reads his ‘sticker’ name tag.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So. You think ‘Cameron’ here wins? (beat) You think being big and tall and overeating immediately just puts a guy at the front of the line? Brandon lets it hang then moves away addressing the group Cameron, relieved to have Brandon out of his personal spa

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In prison I knew men who could shop at Gap for Kids, by that I mean little guys, who were pound for pound tougher than any linebacker. Swear to the mighty Lord. (aside) Now, Jesus was a tough dude. Don’t get me started on that. He looks up at Cameron. Tries to make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s more than triangles and posture and genetics. He offers to shake Cameron’s hand, to which Cameron offer ‘limp’ shake. Brandon casts it aside with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Firm handshakes. Eye contact. Not too much. Looking at women at the right times. The wrong times too. Meanwhile he pushes Cameron fourth down the line.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No offense son. All a process. Fake it. Make it. Jon now takes the prize of ‘manliest.’ Brandon offers a h shake. Jon wants to... but he’s on his ‘no-touch’ promise After a tense pause, he offers one of his salutes.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Military man. G’bless son (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: EXT. BASEBALL BATTING CAGE — DAY Jared and the others line up outside of a batting cage fe We hear the ball being shot out and the grunt of -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, who misses the ball, then miserably hits the secon

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: Who you are on the inside can be affected by the outside. Next. Lee look bewildered, realizing it’s time to step up to th plate. Simon hands Lee the helmet.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Outside in. Fake it till you make it. Adapt to survive. Lee enters as Brandon slides another coin into the slot. There is a terrible anticipation and the first ball comes SHOOTING out. Lee startles.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you kids and folk, being what you are afflicted with -- Lee spins disoriented by the second. Then the third makes awful body contact, tilting the helmet from Lee.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - better learn how to survive. Become the man you are not. Jared sees Brandon smirk, amused, and unwilling to turn o the machine. Lee is swamped and scared. Gary goes in to h

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When you are in a prison, you would surprise yourself -- On Jared absorbing all this as we hear - METALLIC NOISES. GUNS in fact. Guns being loaded. CHK.CHK Magazines being locked. CHK. Firing bolts being racked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An array of HUNTING RIFLES placed on the flatbed tray. Th are four in total, laying side by side.  37A. BRANDON O.S. What you can do to fit in (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rifles are grabbed by their various owners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Jim, Marshall, Jared and a FOURTH MAN edge along a ri deeper into the woods. They split into two groups. - Later, Jared following Marshall, pulls up to rest. Mars urges him on. A SHOT volleys out over the valley. Jared l back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared helps Jim and his father winch a DEAD BUCK onto the back of one of Jim’s trucks  40. INT. CARMEN’S STOP - AFTERNOON Jared, dressed in his hunting gear, finishes off his frie he sits alone. Marshall is at the counter with his glasse paying the check and using easy charm with the WAITRESS. Beside Jared's table is A YOUNG MAN, barely 25, his three KIDS and young wife. There is also two men sitting at a window booth that Jared particularly notices. Just then - CHERYL, who works in the diner, comes up to the table.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Hey Jared.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Oh. Cheryl. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Y'daddy’s pickin’ up everyone's checks again. So sweet. He’s even paying for those two queers -

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: You think they’re...?

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: They have to be. Actually quite nice though. Marshall, now shaking hands with the OLD MAN, calls Jared over. He’s ready to leave. Jared passes the male couple, making eye contact with one of them. An awkward smile. EXT./INT CARMEN’S STOP / MARSHALL'S TRUCK - DAY Once in, Marshall takes a pile of religious pamphlets fro the glove compartment. On one he writes a bible reference Romans 1:27.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: There are two men sitting by the window. I just paid for their lunch. Tell them I'd appreciate them taking a look at this paper and this verse. For their sake. Jared wants to ask why, but is unable. He knows.  40A.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Men committed shameful acts with other men and received in themselves the due penalty for their error. INT. CARMEN’S STOP - DAY Jared walks back into the diner. He looks to where the me enjoy their lunch. Jared looks out the window to where hi father’s truck is in clear view, watching. He moves in th direction holding the pamphlet behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: You guys travelling?

dialogues.speaker: MAN 1
dialogues.text: We are on our way to a wedding in New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Oh. Cool. Um... My father... my father just paid for your lunch. The two men look strangely at this kid in hunting gear.

dialogues.speaker: MAN 1
dialogues.text: What’s the catch?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just... He’s out there - The two men wave out the window. He pockets the flyer.

dialogues.speaker: MAN 1
dialogues.text: Well. Tell him thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Yes Sir. Safe travels.

dialogues.speaker: MAN 1
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared gets back into the truck. Marshall is staring at hi After a long silence --

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What did they say?  40B.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: They said to say thank you. The moment hangs. Does he know that Jared failed the task

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feet hit gravel. Jared and the new group run in a somewha military formation with Brandon as their commander. Aaron follows them driving the short bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared brushes his teeth - his shirt is off. He examines a bruise on the back of his shoulder: a baseball strike? Bu enjoys the wound, like a new sense of his manhood. Then - he catches himself with one hand on his hip. He cl down on the tooth brush and stands ala Brandon: two hands hip; hand back; legs wide - proudly faking it. Soon Nancy joins and they both brush side by side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words “Fake it till you Make it” written on the board Then - Sykes steps into frame, perusing - The bewildered faces of the group staring back. SYKES O.S. Moral Inventory. (beat) Now the real work starts. Catalogue your sins and ask God’s forgiveness for your wrongs. Sarah -- Sarah hesitates to get out of her chair. She finally does passes Aaron who is setting a video camera on a tripod. H secondary task here seems to record significant events.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Sarah facing the group, reading from a handful of papers. is mid-flow. It is painfully awkward hearing her read. Sh trying to motor through it as fast as humanly possible.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: .-..and it was there that I had sinful thoughts of other girls (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - I would look at other girls in the changing rooms before gym. And in the showers. My biggest sin is one that I am also thankful for because it has led me to Love In Action. (beat) I had run away from my uncle’s house and stayed with some girls I knew whose parents were away. And it was there that for a few days I finally acted on my homosexual thoughts. (breathes ) I renounce these sinful thoughts and actions and I ask God to forgive me all these things - Jared watches. He knows that he’ll be up there soon cataloging his own sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sykes sets up the ‘LIE CHAIR’ exercise. Two empty chairs facing each other: a role-playing exercise. Sarah takes one of the seats, waiting with dread. SYKES O.S. Go Sarah. There he is in that chair --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: We smash right into the exercise. Jared watches Sarah be BERATED by Sykes to engage with an invisible family figur Sarah grips the side of her chair. White knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: - staring right back at you. He isn’t. Opposite her is literally an empty chair. Jared turns to check on Jon, who leans forward in his cha Gary beside him, leans back biting his nails.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There he is. Use your words. Spit them out with purpose. Personal pronouns like I said. ‘You’ wronged me. ‘YOU’ showed me sin. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But Sarah keeps thinking. Paralyzed.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t over think it. Nobody’s judging Sarah. But God is watching.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm trying...

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: He’s watching. And He’s waiting.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m trying to find the right words. Sykes unleashes a trial mock tirade on the empty chair.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: ‘You wronged me. You wronged me Uncle...’ what was his name?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Joe.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: ‘You wronged me Uncle Joe -- You took me into the care of your home and locked me up for ---

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It was two of them. Joe and Leila.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: ‘You wronged me Uncle Joe and Aunt - (stops himself) Aaron? Bring me that empty chair. Aaron hustles and Sykes puts it next to the other empty chair. Two chairs for two imaginary people. Behind him we hear a laugh. He swivels, catching Tina with a smirk. SYKES (CONT’D) You think this is funny Tina? You think the reason y’all are here is funny? Take these exercises seriously. Do not waste my time. Each other’s time. God’s time. We are trying to help you. He clicks his fingers in front of Sarah.  42a.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘You wronged me Uncle Joe and Aunt Leila.’ Go! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We wait for Sarah to GO... Instead she starts to tear-up. SYKES (CONT’D) Yes. Yes. Let it out.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Leila wasn’t my aunt. She was my cousin that lived with Uncle Joe.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: (sighs) Alright. Let’s take a break. He checks his watch. Aaron turns off the camera.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sarah can try again tomorrow. Every day, two of you will walk into the arc like Noah’s animals. And get refuge from damnation. This is the ticket of entry. No free rides. He taps the empty chair and meets with Michael who has an urgent issue. Sykes turns, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s tea break, Jared walks over to a shaken Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: You want anything? I’m making a cup of tea. She shakes her head, and as he walks away she stops him -

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You're at the Hampton right? I seen you there. (off his look) Seven o’clock can you meet me by the ATM in the dining area. Bring your phone. Please. Jared nods and moves away, conflicted by the encounter. Through the open door Jared sees Sykes with two PARENTS. somewhat heated: admonishment by the father. Then we see backpack on. The father turns on Sykes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEE’S DAD O.S. We told you that!! Unacceptable. As Sykes moves back toward the door, everyone disperses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and Nancy eat dinner, Jared scarfing down food whil doing his L.I.A. homework and referring to the HANDBOOK. Headphones on, he flicks through his Moleskin with the ri out pages. We see his notes -- Moral Inventory and... Without going into ‘graphic detail catalogue all immoral and sexual experiences & He adds... ‘How you came to be at L.I.A.?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks his watch. Almost seven --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared walks into the hallway leading to the bathrooms. It empty apart from the ATM. Then the bathroom door opens up Sarah peeks through. Seeing Jared she marches over covert and puts her hand out. He hands her his phone and just as quickly she disappears into the bathroom. He waits. Awkwardly. That’s when he sees - Sykes, with a woman and kids, ages six and four. They mov into the restaurant. Seemingly, an average American famil Jared nervously hides behind the ATM and waits guiltily. is he doing? What if he gets caught? Finally Sarah emerges wiping her eyes. She hands Jared th phone and utters -

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Don’t you dare tell anyone. Jared watches her sneak away like she was never even ther

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared gathers his things, aware of Sykes’s presence.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I'll finish this in my room. You ready? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) The head guy is here (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Jared is gone. Nancy follows but looks around wonderi ‘Why is that a bad thing?’ Sykes, hearing clatter, looks up. Did he see Jared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the room, Jared sits on his bed. We push in on him, knowing what his homework is. The building intro of - The Red Hot Chili Peppers - ‘Can' Stop.’ We see Jared's pen move over a fresh page. He writes ‘HEN HENRY O.S. Yo. I got you pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music, emanating from a nearby room continues over -- Jared is struggling up some stairs with two full drawers. Things have started to fall and topple when a fit and tan guy, Henry, bounds up the stairs toward him. Perfect timi

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Here. I can take the top stuff. Jared accepts the help with an awkward thanks. Henry look a drawer as he carries it. It is mainly full of books.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Which room? Just learned a bunch of things about you in half a second looking in this drawer by the way.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? I’m in three-four-six.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I’m in two-three-seven. You run? People who run know about Asics. There are Asics on Jared's feet.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw you unloading from that car with the Razorbacks sticker. You from Arkansas? I’m there a lot (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HENRY (CONT’D) INT. JARED’'S DORM ROOM 346 - MOMENTS LATER The room has a double bunk beds. There is no one else the

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: First one in gets to choose. You got a girl? If so you might wanna apply for a room without bunks.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Just broke up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (winks ) Good timing. Before college. They head for the door. HENRY O.S. I got cousins in Mountain Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and Henry go for a run. We are behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and Henry at one end of the run, sweat heavily and for air. They occasionally look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We're a good fit. Hate running with slow pokes. Or speed freaks. (beat) Tell you what. Race you on the way back. Last one back has to go to the other one’s church. Serious.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Why? What kind of church is it?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You game or not? Jared smiles goofily  47.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ready? After three. One, two, Three, GO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opening POWER CHORDS of a Christian Rock band’s opene Jared and Henry sit among many YOUNG PEOPLE who throw the hands in the air, CHEERING. A Pentecostal Church meeting full swing. More a party than a service.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD SINGER
dialogues.text: Get on your feet for Jesus. Everyone stands and Henry does too. Jared is a beat behin like a guilty outside observer. His dad would HATE this k of worship. Henry offers Jared a hand to stand. Jared sta and watches as Henry, euphoric, cuffs the young TEEN in f of him and lets out a ‘whoop.’

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (beaming) Radical huh? The minister, the YOUNG charismatic FRANK, 35, on the sta

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let's sing it for Jesus --

dialogues.speaker: HENRY / EVERYONE
dialogues.text: Amen/Amen! Henry puts his manly arm around Jared who allows himself smile and start to enjoy it. He relaxes and puts his arm around Henry too. It’s a brotherly embrace that feels saf this environment. But -- The music turns to something synthesized and ominous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and Henry on a run, jog around trees, deflecting ch blossom tree branches to cut a smoother line. Later -  47A. At the end of their run, they stare at each other as they stretch and search for oxygen. Jared tries a smile. But i a little long and Henry frowns, a tad suspicious  48. INT. JARED’S DORM ROOM 346 - LATER That ominous music is a SYNTHETIC LOOP from TOM CLANCY’S SPLINTER CELL. Jared and Henry are still dressed in sweats. We see from behind as Jared controls the game and Henry watches, sipp a beer. A lone player makes his way through the green and blue glow of an underground concrete facility. Jared stea a look at Henry’s face, glowing in the screen’s light. Henry checks his watch. Sips his beer. He’s tired.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Y’said your roommate’s not coming back till tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: On some golf trip. You wanna crash? Jared moves to turn off the game.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You keep playing. Henry gets up and we hear the sounds of Henry climbing up bunk ladder. Jared watches, turns down the sound and then goes back to game, conflicted. He’s attracted it’s clear. But Henry is straight and Jared has ZERO experience with ANYONE. JARED O.S. Am I in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on Jared’s face as a door opens and shuts 0.S.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Have I done something wrong? MICHAEL O.S. Here he comes now. SYKES O.S. Morning Jared.  48A. Sykes sits carrying a file. His demeanor is supremely cas and friendly. Not the ‘man on show’ he is in the group sessions. The only sound is a ticking clock  49.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: No reason to be worried. Around day three I just check in with the new recruits. See how they’re getting along. Little private chat. A poster behind Sykes linking AIDS to homosexual deviant behavior draws Jared’s attention for a moment. SYKES (CONT’D) So, how is it going for ya?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: It’s good. I’m finding it all... helpful, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: How is your Moral Inventory coming along? Are you ready? You wanna go today? Dive right in?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Oh... I, um.. I’d like to watch a couple more people do theirs I think, if that’s okay. I haven’t completed everything yet. Sykes pulls out a handful of papers from his file: Jared' journal stories. He selects a page and holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: It’s a story.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: It’s a love story about a boy and a girl. Were you thinking about two boys when you wrote this? (hold) Is this a true story?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: No. It’s just a story. (off Sykes) Will I be able to get them back? They're assignments for college.  49a.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Yes, I noticed your list of books here. A reading list I assume. (holds it up (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some of these books -- considering everything that’s going on for you, I wonder if this is really the right thing for you to be pursuing at all. Perhaps a year with us is a better use of your time. Something to think about. This troubles Jared, but he nods. Sykes reads him, his ey narrowing a little and then the smile returns -

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen. I want you to know, I've had conversations with your parents in the lead up to you being here, and I know a little of your story somewhat. (smiles) I know there are discrepancies from what your parents were told and what you have said to them. And they are really unsure what to believe. But, I know there is a bigger story. Or stories. Right? We’re not here based on mere thoughts alone. (beat) You know, the ones that get the most out of this, are the ones who are brave. The ones who fess up to what God already sees, Jared. His friendly concern has somehow taken on the air of thre SYKES (CONT’D) You really gotta put it all on the table here. That way we can really assess what is the best future for you. INT/EXT. HALLWAY/SYKES’S OFFICE - DAY SLOW MOTION: Jared walks out. We read his disappointment GARY O.S. Dear heavenly father, today I ask your forgiveness for my sins. Jared takes the corner  51. GARY 0.S. (CONT’D) For a year we lived under the cover of being ‘roommates’ though we weren't using separate rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary goes through the process of reading his Moral Invent He has tears streaming his face. To the side - Aaron is filming with his small mounted camera.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Much like a normal couple we lived that way and for a time... it felt normal... Until my family discovered the truth. But I was fooling myself. Being fooled. I was seduced into sin... by all sorts of sinful people... I knew in my heart I had forsaken Jesus for Satan. Jared listens, frowns. This just seems like a regular, ca relationship being described. He looks across to Jon who can see has a minor black eye. Jon won’t engage.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I am awake to my sins. I can’t believe the disgusting person that I once was. I ask -- The haunting SYNTHETIC music of ‘SPLINTER CELL’ Pulses -- SYKES O.S. Lesbian. Gay. Bi --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the board is a circle with several WORDS inside of it: Marriage, Children, family, support, caring. In an opposi circle is another list: Rape, child molestation, promiscu AIDS , loneliness, zero children -- Sykes writes Heterosexual over the ‘Good/LIFE’ circle, an ‘Homosexual’ and LGBTQ over the other. He adds ‘D’ and ’P well, literally as a joke.  51a.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Transgender, Queer... Dolphins... Pandas, Unicorns. Cupcakes. So much choice over here (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s designed to make everyone laugh, and most don’t but Jared and Jon do. Sykes adds ‘DEATH’ above the circle.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Talk about one way to ruin your dollar bill. To burn it by falling right back into hell. Inviting this behavior into your life -- Move in on Jared as the ‘SPLINTER CELL’ theme riffs. We w recognize it and it will take us back to - INT. JARED’'S DORM ROOM 346 - NIGHT (FLASHBACK) We are taken back to the night Henry crashes in Jared’s d Jared plays alone for a beat but then finishes a game and turns the console off, casting the room into darkness. Later - Jared is lying on his bunk, still awake. Noises c from the springs above: Henry moving. Turning. After a wh

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Can’t sleep, huh? (no answer) Probably shouldn’t run so late at night. Then the figure of Henry jumps down in the darkness. A we moment of pause as Jared turns to look at his silhouette.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Um... Jared frowns. Something in the air. Then - Suddenly, Henry lunges forward and clamps a hand over Jar mouth. Almost gently the command comes -

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shhhh. Shut up. In a weird and almost silent flurry, Jared is forced to f over by Henry. His sweats are pulled down and Henry is on him. During the rapid and silent rape Jared’s head is knocked against the upright strut arm of the bunk. Then it is ove Henry recedes. And all we hear is -  52A. HENRY O.S. Damn it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY 0.S., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on Jared. Paralyzed. His forehead trickles blood. -- We hear Henry climb back up on the top bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared is confused. What the hell just happened? We hold o this for the longest time. Until - Henry starts to cry. Finally, Jared moves ever so slightl

dialogues.speaker: HENRY 0.S., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is wrong with me? What the hell is wrong with me? Jared rolls over onto his back. He listens to Henry cry.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY 0.S., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to be in so much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh man.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Henry? (beat) Have you done that before? Silence. Long.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I need to confess. I’m going to have to... will you hear me? Can you keep this between us? Jared thinks and utters ‘Mmhmm.’ And Henry jumps down. He sits on Jared’s bed. Jared doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. Hold.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember that kid from church. The one in front of us..? INT. JARED’S DORM ROOM 346 - MORNING Jared wakes. Cautiously he stands to see -  54. Henry has gone. The bunk is neatly made, and there’s a no when Jared unfolds it, it merely says - “Run @ 6?" The door opens, startling him: The ROOMMATE, carrying gol clubs, back from his trip. They exchange ‘hellos’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared sits in a class as it is filling up. We push in on Later - he sits alone in the now empty space. Later - he sits outside against a wall, alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry limbers up. Stretches for his run. He looks around Jared: a no-show. He begins texting. Then - JARED O.S. Hey. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Thought you weren't coming.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I nearly had to head home. Henry - curious. Jared starts to stretch.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s all good. My aunt’s a bit sick. I'll probably head back in the morning for a couple days.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Let’s stretch and pray. (off his expression) Why not? For your Aunt. Henry takes a knee, but it doubles as a quad stretch.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dear Heavenly Father... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HENRY (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and Henry run at a medium jog. We follow behind.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY V/O
dialogues.text: We pray that you remove all obstacles from our path. They take a bend.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY V/O, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we give thanks for our freedom, for our youth, and our health, whereas others are less fortunate. We continue to lead them now as Henry looks across to Jar It is clear he is concerned for Jared's withdrawal.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY V/O, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We pray for Jared's aunt, that she May be restored to health and we dedicate this run to her recovery. INT. JARED’S FORD MUSTANG - DAY Jared drives his car. We are behind him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY V/O
dialogues.text: We run guided by your love and lifted by your spirit. Each step a prayer that all of your children share the same abundance. The pair move down a rise and disappear into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry moves with a purpose. A swagger. We follow as he ra a flip cell phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY/JARED V/O
dialogues.text: Amen. Amen. EXT. JARED’S FAMILY HOME - DAY Jared gets out of his car and moves to the house where he greeted with great warmth by his mother  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry on the phone -—

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yo. Hey, you remember a kid called Jared Eamons? Ginger haired kid. Your year at St. Martins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared dumps his bag as he moves through the house. HENRY O.S. I'm looking to get a hold of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry walks the hall dialing a new number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared takes his sneakers off and turns on his computer. T faint 0.S. sounds of a phone ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings in the kitchen. We follow Nancy as she wi her hands and moves to answer.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry opens the wide doors to the college courtyard where hundreds of kids enjoy the sun.
