dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Hi. Is that Missus Nancy Eamons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy is chirpy but somehow senses something ominous.  56A.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: This is she. Who am I speaking to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We hear Henry's mumbled voice on the other end of the lin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move in on Nancy’s ‘not so great’ portrait of the fami now hanging on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes? What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared sits on his bed reading. A knock comes to the door. MARSHALL O.S. Jared? Something in the tone of his voice makes Jared concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SMASH INTO A FIERCE FAMILY ARGUMENT. Jared IS AT WAR w his father. Under interrogation. Nancy is the bystander.

dialogues.speaker: JARED MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Did he give you a name? Answer my question?!

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: If he gave you a name... I’m just saying, why wouldn’t he give you -—

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Answer me. Are you doing all the things he says?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Did he give you his name?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Enough. I command you -

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: - command me all you want. I’m asking questions too. Marshall makes a move toward Jared.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He didn’t give me his name. (wavers ) I don’t think.  57A. They both look to Nancy  58.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: The guy is full of shit!

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Nancy. Leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I'll leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: No. You sit down.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: It’s bullshit, dad.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He just said ‘counselor’. I (a warning) asked for his name -- -- Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: --- and a number but...

dialogues.speaker: JARED MARSHALL
dialogues.text: See. NANCY! Nancy starts to retreat. Finally she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this. Marshall tries a new tactic, trying to focus the conversa

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Okay son... Let’s sit and talk calmly. Man to man.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: No. Dad, because it’s --

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: -- Is it true? He said you've been... that you are a homosexual. Jared sighs deeply. He gets up and moves for the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. We are not finished.  58A.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I am. Because you won’t listen (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jared tries to go to his room. Marshall tries to intercep him. Nancy watches from the hallway. Jared tries to force the door shut which results in a physical battle now with his father. The door hits Marsha face, knocking him backwards and bringing renewed fury. Marshall forces Jared against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Answer me! What this man (correcting) says... - What this full-of-shit guy who is not a counselor and -

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: JARED MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who didn’t have the spine to Son!! give his own name -

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Who raped a kid at his Pentacostal church group. And... God knows who else. Marshall, still grips his son, but is rattled into stilln

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, you're hurting me. Questions rage in his father’s grip. But the thought of hurting his son wakes him from the attack.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad. It’s not true. The guy is lying. I can tell you -- As Marshall slowly releases, Jared steps forward. He take his mother and father flanking him.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: His name is Henry Wallace. He’s not a counselor. He’s a student too. He told me he did some bad things. (beat) I think he thinks I’m going to tell on him. Pause. The dust settles finally. But, Marshall’s radar is tuned to the fact that he doesn’t have ALL the informatio  60. INT. BEDROOM —- NIGHT Jared is playing a game on his PLAYSTATION 2: FINAL DOOM Level 9 with its dread filled pipe-organ theme track. Roa the pit, he blasts demon soldiers and fiery skulls with a double barrel shotgun. Computer blood flows freely. He is deep in burying his reality when his father walks in.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Your mother is making dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I’m okay. I’m not hungry. He pauses the game as Marshall sets down a note pad and p

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I want you to write down this boy’s name and the name of this Pentecostal Church. If he did what you say then it needs to be reported.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I think this matter is a little too important for us to get into the business of protecting anyone. Jared looks at the paper and pen. Marshall moves to leave

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eric is coming over tomorrow to discuss rewiring for the new ministry. (beat) I extended the invitation to Chloe and Brandy too. I'd appreciate it if you stuck around another -

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I really should get back.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: If you can miss one day of classes, I’m sure one more is not going to end the world. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why did you come back in the first place? Mid-week? The way he asks it still feels like he mistrusts his son  61.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know there is nothing like the feeling of... being with a woman. If you knew what it was like -

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Dad. It’s not true. Jared goes to put his head phones on.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You know what I think about those kind of games too. Marshall leaves. Distracted, Jared is swamped by soldiers Game Over. He sits in silence for a moment and then - Jared explodes. The closest thing we have seen to rage. H rips the cord from the controller out of the system and throws it across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall looks at his ministry architectural plans while Nancy preps dinner. A somber mood. Broken as - Jared enters and drops the ENTIRE gaming system on the ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cords and all. BAM.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: You want me to stop with the games? His parents are puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ok... I’1l stop with them. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t want to see Chloe. (beat) We broke up. And he exits, leaving his parents confused. But then - Moments later he is back ---

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We broke up because... I think I’m. In fact, I’m pretty sure that I’m -  61A. Jared is trying to find the words. It’s hard, but he’s go to stay until the message gets across. Finally  62. Marshall swoops up his architect plans, and leaves the ro There is a long pause. Until Nancy awkwardly pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Are you sure honey? INT. JARED’S ROOM - FAMILY HOME - NIGHT Jared is watching through a crack in the door. He sees - In the kitchen his father sitting, embracing his mother. he hears a car and moves to the window. He is alarmed to Two men approach the house: Big Jim and Pastor Wilkes. Marshall walks to greet them. It’s definitely conspirator And it’s definitely something to do with Jared. He moves the landing to watch them enter the house, careful to avo being seen.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming Jim. Pastor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The daily pick-up. Jared goes to collect his cell phone a Jon is leaving the pick-up area, already having taken his see that bruised eye more closely. Jon nods goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and Nancy in profile shuffle back after a long day. Jared's eye catches something and he stops briefly. The BEST WESTERN sign. He and Jon are neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared stands at the window staring at the blue and yellow tower of the BEST WESTERN: Jon’s temporary home. NANCY O.S. We are trying a new place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Jared and Nancy toward the BEST WESTERN. Nancy, always dressed like it’s dinner, even when it’s breakfast  63. NANCY O.S. - in search of the perfect soft- boiled egg. INT. THE BEST WESTERN, BUFFET ROOM — MORNING Nancy holds a bedazzled phone in overly manicured hands. Bangles rattle and rings knock against bigger rings. Meanwhile, Jared scans the room, looking for Jon.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We're about to find out. As Jared cracks the top off a soft-boiled egg, Nancy stretches out those hands in suspenseful expectation: The pantomime of ‘Did they get it right?’ One of their many ‘games.’ Off Jared’s reaction, she clenches her fists: ‘foiled again.’

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Overcooked. (into the phone) If they have an office in Memphis, I could check the color swatches down here. I think a muted green is a good match with oak. Blue is always a little dominant, regardless of shade. Jared goes back to scanning the room. Then he finds - Jon. Trailed by a guy (20s). An older brother Jared guess an even manlier version of Jon. The brother hangs back to talk on his cell, as Jon hits the buffet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared plants himself at the buffet waiting to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Plate? Jared almost answers but then realizes it’s not an offeri for him. Instead - Jon’s brother brushes past.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER
dialogues.text: I said I'll look after myself.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: You want a juice?  63A. And so it comes to be that Jon COMPLETELY IGNORES JARED  64.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER
dialogues.text: Look after yourself. I got mine. Jared hangs, self-consciously filling his plate, until it safe to walk back to the table. INT. THE BEST WESTERN, BUFFET ROOM — MORNING Jared sits back down at the table, stung. He is handed th phone by Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Hey Dad. How’s the remodeling going? He looks across one last time for Jon. No luck.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’m not there to help. (listens) Huh? Oh yeah. Good. It’s fun. (beat) I said it’s fun. PRE-LAP: the SOUNDS OF A GROWN MAN WEEPING. DEEP PAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on Aaron’s video camera. Its red light on. Recordin Phillip sits crying while Aaron films him. The faces of Jared and others as they react to the LIE CH exercise and catharsis. Cameron bites his nails.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: (in between sobs) I hate you. I hate you. I -- Phillip gives his last bit of energy and SOBS now, uncontrollably. Broken. Sykes tentatively helps him up.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Good job Phillip. We love you.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: We love you Phillip.  64a.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: See. Good job. Go wash up if you need. Michael - (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Michael steps forward to escort him. They walk out togeth with Aaron. Jared looks across at Jon, who won’t make eye contact wit him. He looks pissed. He then sees an empty chair. He loo around. Jared turns to look around. Sarah is missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jon is grabbing a boxed lunch. Jared come up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: No one knows where Sarah is. Have you heard anything? He eyeballs Jared briefly. Jared feels scolded.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Is this all a game to you? What were you doing over there anyway?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: We got sick of the breakfast at our place.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (moving off) Okay. You tell yourself that. MOMENTS LATER, Jared sits drinking tea on his own. JON O.S. Listen, man - Jon plants himself in another chair.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: You gotta think about why you went there. Seriously. You don’t think I wasn’t fishing for where you were staying when I told you my hotel. These are the urges we gotta stamp out. Whole reason we’re even here. Gotta control this. He taps his head too hard. Admonishing.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: We were just looking for somewhere that could do boiled eggs properly. Seriously. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: True ownership man. That’s what Moral Inventory’s about. Owning your shit. If you want a boiled egg then tell your place how long you want them cooked. They got a kitchen and eggs and a chef. Don’t come to my place pretending. Or else you gotta add it to your M.I. Jon gives a ‘sure you were’ grunt then jumps up seeing Cameron is throwing a football inside with Tina. He joins sees Cameron, suddenly relaxed and happy to have a footba in his hands. Jared stands too... beside Jon. They take turns throwing to Cameron who is now joined by Tina. The group keep throwing, but suddenly STOP when they hear the door open.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: You don’t have to stop. In the B.G., Sykes starts re-arranging chairs with Michae SYKES O.S. Football is okay. S’long as you don’t break anything. In fact -- Sykes jumps in and starts throwing with them. It becomes awkward but sort of fun. The whole group encouraged to jo in. Some do. Some don’t. Jared watches the madness. Then

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Cameron! ! He throws the ball to Cameron, who catches it happily as

dialogues.speaker: SYKES 0O.S
dialogues.text: You're up. Moral Inventory and Lie Chair. And the carefree smile turns to paralyzing fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cameron is in the chair now. He is doing the Lie Chair exercise. Cameron reads from a piece of paper --

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You wronged me dad and I hate you --  66A. It’s so quiet that everyone has to lean in to hear him. Aaron, behind the camera, gestures to Sykes: ‘volume’  67.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: We can’t hear you Cameron!

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: - hate you for the way you have treated me since you found out about my problems.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: ‘About my sins.’ Say it Cameron. Cameron looks like he wants to disappear. Jared intervene

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I can go. I don’t mind -

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: (shutting him down) Everyone gets a turn. This is Cameron’s turn. Cameron? ‘Found out about my sins’ --

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Found out about my sins.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Louder.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (trying, still soft) -- I hate you because you never listen to me, or acknowledge me. Or if you do acknowledge me it’s to make fun of me --

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: ‘IT’S TO MAKE FUN OF ME!!’

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: -- in front of other people, or - You just yell at me -- Sykes decides to let Cameron work at his own volume. CAMERON (CONT’D) When you told me you wished I hadn’t been born, that really hurt. Cameron stops reading from his notes. He looks at Sykes.  67A.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Well, you say that you are angry, but frankly I don’t see it. ‘That really hurt. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nothing from Cameron) I wanna see you express it. Cameron sighs. Something is definitely inside of him -

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only then can we have a chance to tell these people in the real world how they have affected us. Cameron’s wraps his arms around himself.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is that anger Cameron? You wanna learn and grow? Well? (turns away) I guess not. Oh, well. (to the group) S'up to you. Sykes urges the others to go on break and they all file around Cameron who sits, feeling a failure in the chair - But then - they hear an almighty noise and turn to see - - Cameron bring the chair crashing down like a pick-axe, the empty chair opposite, POUNDING it repeatedly. Everyon in_shock. When the dust settles, they all stare at Camero and Cameron back at them --

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Um. Sorry. Cameron looks around like he has made a mistake. He retre into apologies, and starts to pick up what he’s broken.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: It’s okay. It’s okay. Take a break Cameron. I’1ll get that.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. That’s just how I express my anger so --

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: That’s on me. It’s okay. Good job. We love you Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: We love you Cameron. Cameron passes by, watched by Brandon and applauded by Jo  68A. Jared watches Cameron retreat back into his massive shell  69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared steps up to pee. Unbuttoning, he sees a shape pass high window. Curious, he hoists himself up, and can see - Sykes, alone and in the magical afternoon light staring a the tree line. Hands on his hips. Jared immediately wonde about him. Then the door swings open and Jared steps down BRANDON O.S. You're meant to attend bathroom breaks with a staff member. Brandon eyes him cautiously, and Jared goes to exit --

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: What, you not gonna pee now? Jared realizes his mistake. Looks at his unbuttoned pants

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or were you gonna do something solo? That’s why they make the rules. Jared turns back to pee. It’s a fearful stop-start pee.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sounds like Morse code. You sending me a message, faggot? Finished, Jared goes to walk out. Brandon turns on the ta for him to wash. He complies. Now Brandon gets awful clos and hands him a paper towel.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do not get you guys at all. Too much mothering and not enough fathering. I can’t be both for you. Finally Jared is allowed to leave. INT. NANCY'S CAR — DAY Jared rides back from L.I.A. deep in his head. Nancy driv wondering if she should respect the silence or probe --

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s still early. Do you want to watch a movie (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I got homework still. Plus, I can’t anyway. The rules say all movies contain ‘sinful content.’

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What about an animation?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: ‘What’d you do last night?’ ‘I was hanging at the Hampton Inn watching The Lion King with my mom.’ Jared winds his window down. Nancy turns off the air -

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You want fresh air? Jared reaches out his hand and his hand dances with the a

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know I don’t like - Honey...

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Mom! Who did that happen to and when? Seriously!? Do you know!? Nancy retreats into silence. But Jared is spoiling for a fight.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously. Do you actually know who that happened to? Do you? For real? After another silence -

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was Nobody. From Nowhere Town. (beat) On Highway Zero. It never happened. Now she feels the right to bite back.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Parents want to protect their kids.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: So they feed them lies.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I think those are okay lies.  70A. Jared, realizing he’s been unfairly combative, pulls his back just a little bit  71.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: You know the whole thing you and Dad are paying for here is all about how messed up we are by our parents. They want to know about you. That’s why you can’t know all about it. Cause then they wouldn’t get their money out of you.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What have I ever done to you? I’m not a drunk or a divorcee. Your father and I don’t fight. We barely even raise our voices. (beat) Talk about me however you want, my conscience is clean. Nancy stops. She hit ‘my’ a little too hard. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I should read the book too. (beat) See what it’s all about. Read these rules and what not. (no answer) They get to discuss us. I think we should know about them too. We are paying for it, and trusting them with your care. Jared winds his window up: Happy? He leans against the gl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and his mother schlep down the hallway. Five steps behind his mother Jared’s step is heavy and tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared sits on his bed as his mother showers in the bathro Jared flips open his phone and finds the number Sarah dia two days before. He presses dial after a moment of deliberation. Waits... Then -

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello? Sarah? (beat) Sarah is that you??  71A. Jared hangs up. Soon he turns to find Nancy there  72.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Honey. Is everything okay? He nods. She holds up the handbook. That’s when he notice she has taken it from the nightstand.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm reading it. No debate. I need to know what’s inside of it.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I don’t see why anyone would read it unless you absolutely had to. INT. HAMPTON INN AND SUITES - NANCY’S ROOM We push slowly toward Nancy’s room as - JARED O.S. You can read it at night when I’m here if you seriously want to. (beat) There are tons of spelling errors in it. I almost wanna mark up a copy for them. But - Nancy reads the Love In Action handbook with interest by bedside light. She frowns as we hear -

dialogues.speaker: JARED O.S., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - that would take away the only real enjoyment you get from reading it. Cause, I guess, it's actually not much fun to be there. Whatever she has read - a rule, a task, or an ideology - troubles her. She looks across at her son.

dialogues.speaker: JARED O.S., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At least if you turn to page ‘87' you can enjoy that the goofball that transcribed it was typing so fast - Nancy, remembering, guiltily turns the page to eighty-sev

dialogues.speaker: JARED O.S., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - he wrote ‘Dog' instead of God. We read the line as Nancy’s manicured finger runs along i “,..and so we always come back to Dog’s true design..  73.

dialogues.speaker: JARED O.S., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It'd be a shame to ruin the next poor kid's fun. Tight on Nancy as she smiles ruefully and whispers --

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Almighty Dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy washes dishes. We move in on her slowly from behind The clatter of dishes. Then she stops, rock still. She is crying. And we pull back - there behind her on the table is Jared gaming console. It’s the night Jared declared himself. She hears men entering the house and turns so we see her mascara stained cheeks. She leaves the room. O.S. Sounds of Nancy vomiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy post vomit, steps up to the mirror and, redoes her liner. With each application she calms herself with -

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Everything. Is. Going. To. Be -- Hearing noise she puts on her happy voice.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One minute. JARED O.S. Mom?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes honey?  73A.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Why are Pastor Wilkes and Jim Picard here (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I think your father is having a meeting. (no point lying) Because of that call today and what you just told us. (beat) Pastor Wilkes has dealt with this kind of thing before. Jim’s son Sam. When you were just a boy.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: What did they do to him? Nancy smiles and then laughs. She embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, silly. They didn’t do anything to him. They did things for him. Just like your father is wondering what to do for you. To help you. (beat) You go to your room. Everything is going to be okay. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared sits on the stairs, listening to murmured conversat but not being able to hear clearly. Suddenly Marshall app at the base of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Can we see you in the kitchen please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared, led by his father, enters the kitchen -

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You know Pastor Wilkes and Jim obviously. Jared says his ‘hellos’, curious about the stack of broch of a ‘Christian Nature’ that are piled on the table. The L.I.A. logo of the heart in a triangle is prominent here. His father seems strung out and tired, but there is a paternal care and gentleness that still exists, despite  75.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have one question and then I'11l let you sleep. It’s been a big day. I've shared our conversation with these two fine and trustworthy men and asked for their guidance. Now, we don’t have all the answers but you hold the key to the next step. (beat) In your heart, do you wanna change? Hold. It is a big question.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I have to be forthright here before you answer. I don’t think continuing to live and be part of things at home is going to be easy for you if the answer is ‘no.’ I don’t wanna make that a more bitter pill to swallow, but, if the answer is ‘no’ then I have to be tough and protect my needs with the ministry taking flight and my commitment to my whole flock. (beat) Your mother and I can’t see a way to have you under this roof and attending service and working at the dealership and driving that car if you go against the grain of our beliefs. There it is - an ultimatum. Jared looks at his mother, wh can’t bear to look at him. In that moment he feels alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well son? LONG Pause.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I wanna change.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I was hoping for a quicker answer. But, okay. (beat) Can you be free in the morning for your mother to take you to see Dr. Muldoon? (Jared frowns/nods (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then Pastor Wilkes has invited us to accompany him to the jail tomorrow. (the Pastor’s steely look) Take a seat - They all link hands.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WILKES
dialogues.text: Heavenly Father. Look down on us now with your wisdom and unleash your power for one of your flock Jared, who has lost his way. We pray Lord that you make _him pure. Sound starts to fade out -- PASTOR WILKES (CONT’D) And deliver him safely back to us. See the errors of his mind as nothing more than what it is - a momentary straying... EXT. ARKANSAS STRIP MALL — MORNING Jared and his mother walk. We follow them. Nancy puts on dark glasses. She turns to look over her shoulder, like s is nervous they are being watched. That people know. INT. DR. MULDOON’S WAITING ROOM —- MORNING Jared sits in a waiting room with a couple other folk. Th door opens and Nancy and Dr. Beverly Muldoon (45) come ou

dialogues.speaker: DR. MULDOON
dialogues.text: Jared. (to Nancy) I'll see him alone if that’s okay. Nancy takes Jared’s seat. INT. DR. MULDOON’S OFFICE - DAY Jared sits opposite doctor Jane.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MULDOON
dialogues.text: Your father has asked me to take some of your blood and check for testosterone levels Jared. Is that okay with you (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DR. MULDOON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He shrugs. He nods. DR. MULDOON (CONT’D) You know, anything we discuss here is just between you and me. Both ways. I hope that’s okay? She leans forward with kindness. DR. MULDOON (CONT’D) I’m in a little bind here Jared. And I said this to your mother too. Now I’m a religious woman no question, but I’ve also been to medical school. So I guess you could say I hold science in one hand and God in the other. And that’s not always an easy balance. Jared seems confused so she drops the round-a-bout speak. On Jared. DR. MULDOON (CONT’D) We won't find any answers in your blood Jared. I wish I could say otherwise. And then send you to the pharmacy for a pill that will magically fix you. But that’s not going to happen. DR. MULDOON (CONT’D) I’m going to take your blood and I know what it will tell me. That you are a perfectly normal and very healthy teenage boy. It’s not my place to tell you your parents are wrong. But... (beat) There is a different opinion - a medical one - that says that they are wrong. And well - (it hangs) What happens next is still your choice. It may not feel that way, but it is. That’s all. Jared hears what she is saying. He’s just not sure yet exactly what the ‘next’ is. DR. MULDOON (CONT’D) Do you have any questions for me (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DR. MULDOON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He doesn’t. She looks at him with a maternal air and then knowing what may be ahead of him, offers him this - DR. MULDOON (CONT’D) Well, just know you can call me any time. Now or anytime in the future. She slides her card writing her cell number on the back. saw this card during Jared's induction into L.I.A.) DR. MULDOON (CONT’D) Okay. Which arm you want me to excavate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared, alone, eats. His sleeves are rolled up and a cotto bud taped in the crook of his left arm. He watches - Through the glass, Nancy and Marshall in conversation wit Big Jim. Jim heads for the lunch room.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Hey pal. Your father wanted me to show you something. (beat) I think your mom told you about my son Sam. Ten years ago he was in the same spot you’re in pretty much. Here - Jared looks at the photo Jim hands him. A happy family portrait. A smiling middle-aged guy, a slightly overweigh woman and their three children: a girl 8, and twin boys 5

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is him today. Happy as a clam. (beat) Don’t know if that helps. But... it’s all possible my friend. Marshall knocks on the door. ‘Ready?’ Jim tucks the photo back in his pocket, and pats Jared on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m rooting for ya pal.  78A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared trails Pastor Wilkes and Marshall as they go throug the prison security check  79. . A big multi-bag of peanut M&M’s gets scanned along with three King James Bibles and pamphlets.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Candy to anyone who can recite at least two verses from the bible. (beat) If a want for candy tricks them into finding truth in the gospel, then -- We have to appeal to their lower natures before we can appeal to their higher ones. Jared nods. Marshall, seeing Jared's fear, offers hima reassuring pat on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared, terrified and wary, stands carrying the M&M bags. watches as his father consoles a prisoner with truly grea compassion. Then he hears his name called. Pastor Wilkes needs a bag of M&M’s. Jared steps closer to the cell he i in, trying not to make eye contact with the prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WILKES
dialogues.text: This is where the fallen land. You see? Look around you son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall and Jared approach the car. Marshall eats M&M’s. Then hands the bag to Jared, who is still deep in memory the pastor’s warning. They get in -

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You going to stay for dinner? Or --

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I should probably make a start today. Hold. Marshall puts his hand on Jared’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: We'll get through this son. Then Marshall turns on the radio: Credence Clearwater rev blasts out: There’s a Bad Moon on the Rise  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared on the side of the highway, where people only usual stop because their car has broken down. He is in the mids a_ panic attack: trying to regulate his breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets out and closes the door, leaning against the car. manages to calm himself a little. VRrrrmmm. The sounds of trucks racing past by catches his attention. Soon he steps forward, until -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is very close to the edge. Might he just step forward solve all his problems on the grill of a speeding semi? O driver HONKS a warning. Finally - Jared walks back to the car, kicking out at the side mirr breaking it. He gets back in the car and starts the ignit His complicated life must keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy wakes up. She looks around. Jared is gone. On his freshly made bed, she finds a note -

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Decided to walk x c u @ 5. Sorry I was mean. She finds a screwed up paper on the floor and unfurls it.

dialogues.speaker: PAPER
dialogues.text: ‘Moral Inventory.’ ‘Henry’ and ‘Xavier.’ Henry has been scratched out. Nancy seems concerned. She moves to the bed and covers herself entirely with the she Hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared walks along the gravelled edge of the highway. He r a handful of pages, rehearsing for his Moral Inventory. Then - A pick-up pulls next to him. Jon’s brother's car.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yo. Need a ride?  80A. Jared sees Jon’s brother in the driver’s seat, eyes front  81.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Thanks, but I got a little while. I thought I'd walk. Looking through my stuff for today. Jon understands: ‘Okay.’ The pick-up pushes on. Then -— Up ahead, it slows and stops. Then Jon gets out, slamming door. His brother blasts the horn and completes a screech U-turn as Jon walks toward Jared. Shrugs it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared and Jon have taken a short cut through a park. Jare waits as Jon finishes peeing behind an old abandoned car.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: So, I got all these feelings in me, obviously. Toward men and so on. Have since I was thirteen or so. But I never did anything about it. Then, when I got older and discovered booze, I’d get real drunk and I’d let my guard down. Basically I’d wrestle guys and fight just to get the contact ina way that seemed okay. But, you know, people started to notice and talk. Guess I’d go too far too often. (beat) Then, one party, I get real drunk, I mean like super crazy drunk and, while a bunch of people are cheering me and watching me wrestle this kid, I kiss this dude, like full on, on the mouth. (beat) I think in my haze I thought it was okay ‘cause I figured it would look like a domination over a kid everyone was already suspect over. Jared listens, deeply curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I guess, I realized in the moment how it looked to everyone and I tried to start the wrestling charade again (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .- But when I saw it wasn’t working, I had to do something and so -- (He sighs deeply) I really started to whale on this kid... like choked him out and beat his face in... like bad, bad, bad, bad, bad. Bad. (beat) And when it was done I remember I stood up all messy, and put my fist in the air like I’d just won at the U.F.C or something whack... and I was waiting for the cheers, and -- Jared waits - walks - Pause. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone's faces were like... dead still. Like -‘What the fuck just happened! ?!?'

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I haven't been home since. (beat) I'm sorry for it. But it’s also what got me to where I am. So...

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I’m committed, I’m not here to waste anyone’s time, don’t get me wrong, but - (beat) - I am what I am. I don’t think there is any changing me and my thoughts and whatnot. But I do know by staying off the drink and making certain choices, I can just choke that side of me away. Put it aside. There is a difference. Whether you can actually change or just choose different things. Jared absorbs this. Jon knows he can’t change. He just believes he can put his desires in a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Haven’t touched another guy since. That’s why I don’t even shake hands you know. I’ve just decided that’s it for me. Whatever it takes (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jon kicks a rock.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you got? (beat) What’s your big crazy story? Jared absorbs what he has on his meager pages...

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sykes’s gonna decide you know, based on what you say today, whether you stay another month, three months, six. A year. Finally, Jared stops.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I don’t really have a crazy story. We, ah, probably shouldn’t walk in together. And they walk in silence for some time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared approaches to see Sykes on the steps conferring wit two OLDER MEN. One, a striking man with silver hair and s features and, a shiny-bald stocky man. Both in their fift Sykes sees Jared.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Today's going to run a little differently. I’1l be inside soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is trash bag in the center of the room and, from it the members of the group are trying on black and dark-blu blazer coats as instructed by Michael and Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: What’s going on Michael?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Sykes can tell you. Try this on. Jon and Jared try on coats. They are handed ties too as - Sykes enters looking troubled  84.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Everybody sit down. Michael. Aaron. You can start on the windows. Jared sees a MASSIVE roll of black material. Duct tape et He wonders: “what the hell is going on?!?” And then the door opens and a couple of STAFF lug a funer casket into the room. Aaron runs to help.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. We haven’t got much time and I need your help. Sykes signs for the casket. Then he turns to the group.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s been a situation with Cameron overnight. Everyone sinks. Is Cameron dead?!?!

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cameron has broken some serious rules and in conference with his father and their church elders, we've decided to offer hima chance. To shock him into recovery. Jared is confused.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Today Cameron is going to choose to be dead to his life and to his family or to truly surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is now cast in darkness, the windows blacked out Candles flicker and dim lamps otherwise illuminate the ro The centerpiece is the casket. Slivers of sun infiltrate. Jared, Simon, Jon, Carl... all are in attendance. Jared looks across to a handful of NEW PEOPLE: CAMERON’S FAMILY and CLOSE FRIENDS: An OLDER BROTHER and SISTER. An TWO YOUNGER SIBLINGS. The two younger ones are confused a are teary-eyed. CAMERON’S MOTHER also attends along with Cameron’s LOCAL MINISTER (the balding man we saw earlier. Plus a couple of FOOTBALL TEAMMATES, along with their COA  84a. Sykes enters. He gestures for everyone to stand. He grabs chair and sets it down beside the casket, facing the grou  85.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Here? The BALD MAN nods approval. Sykes is not in control here. Then a knock at the door alerts him -- Sykes opens the door. Cameron, BLINDFOLDED, is led by his FATHER and Rev. Neil, the silver haired man. Jared looks deeply concerned: It looks more backyard, improvised and pagan-like than truly Christian. Brandon starts a classic funeral dirge on the Hi-fi syste OPUS 35 - Chopin. Cameron is taken to his seat by the casket. They unmask h and, when he sees his family gathered together plus the casket, his weeping deepens. Understandably, he is scared Jared squirms.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND NEIL
dialogues.text: Sadly, we are gathered here today to say farewell to our son, our brother and friend Cameron Van Huessen who, by his own making, last night fell prey to Satan’s wishes, falling farther away from God. (beat) But, the Heavenly Father in the wisdom of his mercy hasn't had his last word on this boy’s soul - Jared watches as -- -- Music starts drowning out the ‘service.’ The beatific Moonlight Sonata by Beethoven. ----- as it plays, we see ----- Various images in slow motion to the music. - Cameron wraps himself in his big arms and folds over. S attends him, holding him in place. - Cameron's sisters hug each other. - The bald Minister opens the coffin as Cameron is led th by Sykes and Rev. Neil. A pantomime where the message is clear. Does Cameron want to DIE or BE REBORN.  85A. - Cameron shakes his head fervently. He doesn't want to d  86. - They crowd around Cameron, offering an ultimatum. He no his head, still in tears, fully submitting. - Sykes gestures to Aaron and Michael who rip the black material off the walls letting the light in. - Cameron kneels, eyes shut, hands up, surrendering himse Rev. Neil places a hand on Cameron's head. In a wild, jol gesture he PUSHES to CAST the demons out. - Others join him, doing the same. - Cameron's Father pushes Cameron's head aggressively. Cameron falls backwards to the ground. - Cameron's brother is handed a bible. He strikes Cameron with it. Cameron's anguished face as he rolls over, tears streaming. - Various people are encouraged to strike Cameron with bi and other books. Harder and harder they strike. - Later: Cameron vomits in a trash can held by Brandon. R Neil brings him back to his knees. - Jon is handed a bible. He stands, Jared watching him. - Jon strikes Cameron with the bible. - Cameron stands with the help of those around him. His sisters are close. The music carries through - EXT. DRIVEWAY/STREETS — LATER - Cameron walks the street, propped up by his father and others. The full congregation snakes behind. Jared is right up the back. Sarah near him. They share a look. - They walk up the path toward a house: New Hope House. T Men’s ‘long stay’ house we have been hearing of. Follow i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen, through Jared's P.O.V.: A suburban house with all d removed and closed circuit surveillance cameras in the co of EACH ROOM. HE notices, as they pass -  86A. The ONLY DOOR in the house. It has two PADLOCKS securing  87. INT. NEW HOPE HOUSE, BATHROOM -— DAY Jared watches through the crowd as Cameron is placed in t basic shower bath-tub of the small bathroom. There he is baptized with his father and mother close, encouraged by Rev. Neil to place their hands on him. His big body shudders and his strong arms reach out for t water. Like a massive baby. Full surrender. Jared watches mute. The only thing that makes this even remotely bearable is Cameron, seems ecstatic and accepting of his REBIRTH. His arms clawing for God, reaching for a loving embrace. Beethoven's music underpins the whole horrible, beautiful scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared sees Sykes on the edge of the action, involved but really. Jared turns to go, unable to watch anymore. Interestingly, Sykes doesn't try and stop him. But - Jon does. He grabs for Jared's arm. Jared shakes him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared moves into the hall, escaping the horror. He is alo GARY O.S. Starting to see it for what it is? Gary is standing by the corner.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: They catch him with another boy in a steam room and what do they do? (beat) You seem smart. You want my advice? Tell them everything they need to hear and play the part. You’re up any day now. Let them know you’re understanding your mistakes, getting better, that it’s working. Think all my stories and my tears were real? ‘Fake it to make it’. None of this is going to help any. The sooner you are out of here and home the better. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the sooner we are all out of home and somewhere else the better - (that hangs (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t want to end up at one of these houses for any amount of time. I’ve heard the stories and they are not good. A muffled chorus and shout comes from the bathroom. GARY (CONT’D) Unless you really think you can change. Or want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music continues as - Jared walks the hall with his mother. Seen from behind th walk away and enter the room, leaving an empty hallway. H And the music ends on a deep base note -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared runs, exorcising the days events. Hood up, he pound the pavement past the various motels. The rushing oncomin cars WHOOSH past like his dark thoughts. Later: As he passes a bus shelter he comes to a stop. A s mall in the background. Not a soul about. He takes a seat a bench to catch his breath and when he looks back he see On the outside of the bus shelter: a beatific advertising image of a SHIRTLESS GUY, lit and inviting. Jared looks a but something draws him back. His nature. Then, something fierce wells up in him, and he gets up as he is looking around for something. Leaves frame. Hold. W hear noises of effort. He soon returns with a heavy paving stone. He is about to launch the missile at the advertising image. However -- On the approach, the poster slides to the NEXT ad... a wo in a swim suit. It railroads his intentions.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Arghhhh. He throws the paver anyway and it bounces off the Perspex shield, doing minimal damage. He sits down drained. Defea  89.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck. (turning skyward) Fuck you. I hate you. Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: FUUUUUUCK
dialogues.text: He waits. Nothing. Then -— The advertising image slides back, to the beatific male image. But, now buckled by the assault, its mechanism fal and sticks halfway. We move in on Jared. Recognition. Mem The man, the face, albeit obscured with fracture glass, reminds him of something. Someone.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON, (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Jared parks the car. He is dressed as he was the day of t prison visit. The day he had his panic attack on the high and had thoughts of suicide. We know this too because whe gets out, he inspects the freshly broken side window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared lugs his overnight bag, dragging his feet. Depleted He lumbers past a bulletin board, then stops. Backs up. An image of Christ. It’s a western depiction of Jesus whe the man himself could have signed with a California model agency. The words ‘God vs. Science’ pop out. He steps closer and takes the flyer in his hands. It is advertising for a college art exhibition. EXT. JARED’S DORM ROOM 346 - NIGHT Jared unlocks his room. He notices, behind him, TWO STUDE whisper gossip about him. Has word gotten around somehow? Then he looks into the room - INT. JARED’S DORM ROOM 346 - NIGHT Inside, his room has been trashed. He enters cautiously.  890. Then he stops - Just above his bunk bed mattress is a cru spray-painted message: ‘DIE HOMO.  90. - He corrects a fallen chair and finds a bottle of wine. - Room fixed up, Jared sits on his bed holding the bottle turns over the flyer in his hands then puts it aside. He opens the bottle sniffing the booze: ‘Die Fag’ behind him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A section of the Fine Arts building turned gallery space. People mill about. A decent crowd. Jared steps into frame He raises a glass of wine to his lips. He is staring at - The Mormon style image of Jesus. The same ultra-color Blo depiction as the flyer. The actual artwork is five feet b six. HUGE. We see that in Jesus’s hand is an image of a C PHONE. It’s controversial in a playful way. To Jared it is distasteful and somewhat irrelevant. Trite turns and places his drink down and suddenly stops, seein A BEAUTIFUL BOY (20), gesturing to a small group about an image: MARY. Arms in offering, a Virtual Reality system o her face. Someone in the group shakes his hands in congratulations, and he nods humbly in thanks. This is th ARTIST. Xavier. Jared is transfixed. Not by the image, but by Xavier. And then Xavier catches him and looks right back. He step front of the image so that he appears Jesus-like. Divine: Mary's offering arms seem to be his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared does not turn away. Xavier gestures ‘cheers’ with h wine and moves away. Jared keeps staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared walks an expansive hallway alone. Soon - Xavier comes into frame, following. Then he takes the lea  90A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in together. As the door closes the music stops  gl. There is minimal improvised and eclectic furniture in thi studio space. Beyond it Jared can see at the far end, a b room lit by warm lamp light. Xavier puts on Otis Redding - Change is Gonna Come. Vinyl

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER O.S
dialogues.text: I’m having some wine. Do you want some more? When Xavier speaks he has a slight European accent: Frenc Swiss? It is hard to tell. Jared looks around at the motley pictures hanging: Subver religious images; magazine cut-outs, plus; sketches of pe and shapes. Curated by a novice, yet somehow captivating.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Where are you from Xavier?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER O.S
dialogues.text: I lived in thirteen countries before I left high school. Born in Vienna. Ended up in Canada. Now here. He approaches with a red wine. Jared takes it.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Do you believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Serious.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Why is that serious? Jared is buoyed by drink. It is a bold side of him we hav never seen. Perhaps some things are possible with booze t otherwise are not, as we may remember from Jon’s tale. Like with that - this encounter should carry an edge that carries the possibility of that same danger.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you believe in God or not? Your whole art thing is --

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: I do. I was raised with religion and I question it, but I still believe in God (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Who created the earth? Xavier laughs. That’s a BIG question?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: You like a little small talk, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I don’t think you can believe in science and religion equally. Xavier frowns, not ready to engage in the seriousness.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t you think you have to pick a side? Don’t they cancel each other out.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Well, paper beats rock. Then no one can believe in God.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Because science has shown itself and God has not.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Sure he has.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Not all the time. Science shows itself all the time. It’s always around us developing. Does God show himself enough? Where is He? (off Jared's expression) Wait till you really suffer. Jared seems to be getting either angry now or emotional. may lash out, physically OR sexually... or totally crumbl It is hard to tell. Xavier walks away. When he comes back, he has a joint. He lights it. Jared h never been this close to drugs.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you believe in the devil?  92a. Jared's silence is a yes  93.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does he look like me?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Because he also doesn’t show himself. Jared surprises us by taking the joint. He takes a toke. After a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: You know Job? From the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Not personally. Jared sees the humor in it.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hear he’s not great company. Always complaining. Jared cracks up. Then gets real. He has to make his point

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I imagine I’m him sometimes. That God and the Devil are having a bet over me. That one day he’1ll show himself to me and let me in on the experiment he was having to test me.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: You just summed it all up. (beat) People hoping someone is watching over them. That hard times are part of a design. (beat) I think we are our own test. Our own judgement. Our own god. Meaning I think he is in us. All of us. Not somewhere watching and hiding. Jared thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stay with me.  93A. Jared is not flinching  94.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing needs to happen. I swear. Nothing from Jared.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1ll prove to you that God won’t strike you down.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: What if you are the devil?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Then you are too. He backs away. XAVIER O.S. We are the same. I could be you or you could be me. Soon, Jared looks back for the door, but instead he watch Xavier who disappears into the warm glow of his bedroom d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above, Jared and Xavier lie down. The music filters from the other room. They look at each other. They hold hands. And that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared wakes up to full sunlight. Xavier is facing him asl Jared looks down. They are still holding hands, and still fully clothed. Jared slowly releases his hand from Xavier He stares for some time then finally moves out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared walks the street and lifts his phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Dad. I’m ready. I’m coming home. I’1ll go wherever you need me to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared naked from the waist up.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Please Lord, make me pure. And falls backward, right into the icy college lake. His clothes left piled on the shore nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared, dripping wet, stands before the mirror in his runn gear, staring at himself. The shower runs in the B.G. The realize that he is looking at a card. It is the business of Dr. Beverly Muldoon. He turns it over in his hands. Contemplating. Phone poised he actually starts to dial. T he thinks better of it and takes off his shirt, walking i the steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind: Nancy, in her Jackie O’s, and Jared walk the hall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind: Jared walks the L.I.A. hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared sits in his chair, clutching his papers and handboo purposeful steely look in on his face. He looks across an Cameron slowly eases himself into an empty seat. He acknowledges no one and sits, arms across his massive tor Sykes moves to his podium.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: I don’t know about y’all, but today I feel invigorated. I feel hopeful that so much is possible. Jared steals a look at Cameron. Cameron does not seem to sharing the same vigor. He seems truly sunk.  95A.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cameron. How do you feel (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I feel great, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Do you feel the true presence of God in your heart?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: It feels great don’t it?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yes sir. It does for sure. Jared catches Gary’s eye. A shared skepticism. Then he catches Jon’s eye, but Jared turns away almost coldly. Th have shifted between the two of them. Broken. SYKES O.S. Ready when you are, Jared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared's hands squeeze his papers for his Moral Inventory. We hold on Jared's face through --

dialogues.speaker: JARED

dialogues.text: (he knows ) Listen I don’t want to get into a fight. Your mother told me about -

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: It’s not a fight. I’m just doing the right thing. Letting you know. (beat) I’ve written more, and the publishers are talking about me putting together a whole book. You don’t need to read any of it, but I just needed you to know that it might be out there. And --

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, now I know. Jared is arming up for a confrontation. Hard as it is.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: But, it might be good for you to read... because you also never really asked what went on there. (beat) You never really knew the staff or - And Marshall continues inside, leaving Jared unresolved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall makes notes for a sermon, his bible beside him. Suddenly, a newspaper placed down: Jared’s article (A few fact). Nancy holds Marshall's look. She picks up the bibl

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I think you’ve read that one. He goes to take her hand but she moves off. We see Jared the background, like he did the night Pastor Wilkes and J helped determine his fate, peering through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared loads his car. He closes the trunk. He looks to the house. His dad is not coming to say goodbye. He hugs his  116A. Jared is about to drive away. But his mom knocks on the window and Marshall appears at the passenger window.  117.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You mind driving me to the dealership? Got some stuff to organize. Marshall gets in and they pull away. Nancy waves good bye

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. JARED'S CAR —- EARLY MORNING Jared drives and looks across to - Marshall deep in thoug his eyes trained to the front. EXT. CAR DEALERSHIP —- MORNING Jared gets out of the car as his father moves toward the entrance. His father turns --

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Come on in for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall turns, looking around in the expansive showroom. seems confused. Agitated.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Is there anything you need help with? Otherwise I should -- Jared turns hesitantly, to leave. But then -

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Hold on. This was going to be for Christmas. (he hands Jared keys) It’s an Explorer. Your mother said you and your friends drive up --

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Dad. I live in New York. I don’t need a car. (beat) I don’t want to pretend anymore. It’s okay Dad. I’m okay without all this. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unless we are going to speak to each other properly. Like - (beat (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gay. I’m gay and I’m your son. And neither of those things are going to change. Hold. Marshall breathes. He looks out over the dealership

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: This was all going to be yours you know? (beat) Still will be. I meant, to run and make a living from. But, I know you got other fish to fry. (beat) I ran your grandfather’s mill, like he wanted, until I had the gall to tell him I didn’t want that. He is still looking around, not making eye contact. Then

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I stayed up all night trying to think of good reasons to convince you to keep everything to yourself... the book and whatnot... but then I thought that would be like your grandpa forcing me to run the mill. Jared listens.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like to do what I want, so who am I to get in anybody else’s way? He turns to Jared.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The truth is I do want you to do well and have a good life. I know we don’t agree on a handful of things. And, I realize by what’s happened, I’ve set myself up to lose you. I had to ask myself and God if I was ready for that. (beat) Your mother said a prayer that she got comfort from. Whether it was her that needed to change and not you... My prayer didn’t so much give me comfort. I don’t think I am ready to lose you and so I wanted to let you know - (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marshall is not the eloquent man he was in church.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- that I am going to try. I’m sorry it’s not more, and I understand if that is not good enough for you. That’s on me. (beat) Son, I tend to be more eloquent in front of full congregation than this. I guess, I prepare for that. He takes a big breath in and out. Smiles ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘I’m trying’ is the subject of today’s sermon. Marshall hangs his head. Jared steps forward and hugs him

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Mom is coming to New York for Christmas. You are welcome to come too. Have a think about it. Hold wide as father and son embrace. Then Jared removes himself and sets the keys down. If It Be Your Will - by Leonard Cohen as sung by Antony a the Johnsons starts and carries through --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. JARED'S CAR — DAY Jared drives free and alone along a stretch of Arkansas countryside. He cracks the window to let in the warm bree And his hand goes out the window to dance in that breeze.

dialogues.speaker: ----- CREDITS -----
dialogues.text: Footnote. L.I.A. was dismantled in 2012. Despite being discredited by the American Psychiatric Society, it is still legal in 45 states of America for parents to commit their children to conversion therapy. Practices of electric shock, solitary confinement, and various other forms of physical and psychological abuse h been reported  120. Sykes left L.I.A. in 2005. He is now openly gay and marri to a man in Paris Texas, U.S.A. This film is dedicated to all the victims. Alive and dead Leonard Cohen --- If it be your will. If there is a choic Let the rivers fill. Let the hills rejoice.
